column2: Obìnrin arúgbó lásán làsàn. Obìnrin arúgbó ráda…….rádaràda. Níbo?

column1: Tell me where…did I meet you first… first time…Never met you before! You terri…terrible ol’ woman!’
column2: Sọ fún mi, níbo…….ni mo ti pàdé rẹnígbà àkọ́……..àkọ́kọ́…………N kò pàdé rẹ rí! Ìwọ obìnrin arúgbó rádaràda………….”

column1: Alamu laughed, let go his hands, and grrh – grrh –grrh! – down came the contents of his bowel in a prolonged vomit that left  Labake’s dress thoroughly drenched and soiled!
column2: Àlàmú rẹ́rìn-ín, ó tú ọwọ́ rẹ̀ kúrò…….ó ṣe gììrì………gììrì…….gbogbo ohun tó wà nínú agbẹ̀du rẹ̀ pátápátá ni óbì jáde. Ẹ̀wù ọrùn Làbákẹ́ ni óbì sí, ẹ̀wù náàsì rin kínkín.

column1: Then he started coughing… The more he coughed, the more the waste product inside his bowel gushed out through the mouth and nostrils!
column2: Lẹ́yìn náà ni ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í húkọ́, bí ó ṣe húkọ́ yìí ni àwọn èsùn pàǹtí yòókù tí ó wà ní agbẹ̀du rẹ̀ ń jáde láti ẹnu àti ihò imú rẹ̀!

column1: It was a moment Labake would never forget. She did not sleep at all through the night, she thought over what exactly the matter could be with her husband.
column2: Àsìkòyìí jẹ́ àsìkò tí Làbákẹ́ kò lè gbàgbé láéláé. Kò fi ojú kan oorun rárá ní gbogbo òru, ó ń ro ohun náà pàtó tí ó lè máa ṣe ọkọ rẹ̀.

column1: She had heard him talk several times to himself in his sleep, she had heard that strange laughter many times.
column2: Ó ti máa ń gbọ́ tí ọkọ rẹ̀ dá sọ̀rọ̀ lójú oorun láìmọye ìgbà, ó ti gbọ́ ẹ̀rín abàmì tí ọkọ rẹ̀ ń rín níìgbà púpọ̀.

column1: And now for Alamu, it was ‘weed weed and wine… wine wine and weed!’
column2: Nísinsìnyí, ọ̀rọ̀ Àlàmú ti di igbó igbó fí fààti ọtí mímu………ọtí mímu àti igbó fífà.

column1: what could make him so desperate? Something obviously was amiss. The truth must be discovered…
column2: Kíni nǹkan tí ó lè sọ ọ́ di ọ̀dájú báyìí? Dájú dájú nǹkankan ń kán. Ó sì gbọ́dọ̀ wádìí òtító...

column1: She set about that in a business-like fashion, following her husband all about the house like a shadow. For many days, she kept azing intently at him, watching his demeanour, watching his comportment.
column2: Ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ èyí ní pẹrẹ, ó ń tẹ̀lé ọkọ rẹ̀ káàkiri inú ilébí i òjìjí. Fún ọjọ́ púpọ̀, ó ń tẹjú mọ́ ọn, ó ń wo ìṣesí rẹ̀.

column1: She followed him to the sitting room and engaged him in conversation, she accompanied him to the car park to wash the car. At the backyard of the house, they were always together – with labake taking note of every word, every utterance her husband made.
column2: Ó tẹ̀lé e lọ sí yàrá ìgbàlejò, ó sì ń bá a tàkùrọ̀sọ, ó tún sìn ín lọ sí ọgbà ìgbọ́kọ̀sí láti bá a fọ ọkọ̀ rẹ̀ ní ẹ̀hìn kùlé ilé wọn, wọ́njọ ń wà papọ̀ -  Làbákẹ́ sì ń ṣàkíyèsí gbogbo ọ̀rọ̀ ẹnu rẹ̀.

column1: And whenever Alamu went inside the toilet, Labake too was always around, peeping through the key hole of the toilet, watching.
column2: Nígbàkugbà tí Àlàmú bá wọ ilé ìtọ̀, Làbáké náà ádúró nítòsí, á máa yọjú láti ibi ihò kọ́kọ́rọ́ ilèkùn ilé ìtọ̀.

column1: All she got for her pains were occasional grins and grunts, incoherent phrases and incomplete sentences from her husband.
column2: Gbogbo ohun tí Làbákẹ́ ń rí gbà lọ́wọ́ ọkọ rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí èsì sí gbogbo wàhálà rẹ̀ yìí kò ju gbígbin, kíkùn tàbí àkùdè gbólóhùn àti ọ̀rọ̀ júujùu.

column1: Alamu would begin a sentence well then break off absent-mindedly, with a hiss, a moan or laughter.
column2: Àlàmú á bẹ̀rẹ̀ gbólóhùn kan dáadáa, á sì dánudúró lójijì, pẹ̀lú òṣé, kíkùn tàbí ẹ̀rín.

column1: I will have to be there hum-hum-hum… And when ah-ah-ah get there…’
column2: “Mo ní láti wà níbè hùn hùn hùn……tí mo bá ha ha ha ha………sì dé bẹ̀…………”

column1: ‘Yes, I must go there, and em…e… explain the aspect of em…em…’ ‘But wait – a little clarification is hum – hum- well… necessary here… I hope to convince em…
column2: “Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo gbọ́dọ̀ lọ síbẹ̀ kí n ẹm…..ẹ̀ ṣàlàyé ìrísí ẹm…….ẹm……..dúró ná, àrídájú kékeré kan hùn…hùn….hùn….hùn ṣe pàtàkì báyìí……..mo ní ìrètí láti yíwọn lọ́kàn padà ẹm…..

column1: This one thing to tell em… o.k. let it remain like… like… until tonight when I… em… em…’
column2: Èyí jẹ́ nǹkankan láti sọfúnwọn…..ẹm ẹm……ó dáa…..jẹ́ kí ó wá…..wá…..títí dalẹ́ nígbà tí n……ẹm…..ẹm”.

column1: There was nothing Labake could do to make Alamu complete his sentence. He would gesticulate, nod his head, point a finger, tap the table and that would be the end of that sentence!
column2: Kò sí ohun tí Làbákẹ́ lè ṣe láti jẹ́kí Àlàmú parí gbólóhùn rẹ̀. Bí ó bá ti fi gbogbo ara sọ̀rọ̀ bíi kíkan orí mọ́lẹ̀, kí ó nawọ́, kí ó kan tábìlì, ó ti parí gbólóhùn náà nìyẹn!

column1: But Labake got one fact out of it all, and that was what she now held unto.
column2: Àmọ́, Làbákẹ́ ti rí àrídájú kan mú jáde nínú gbogbo èyí, òhun tí ó sìfúnka mọ́ nìyí.

column1: ALL Alamu’s uncompleted sentences had to do with going somewhere to visit somebody to fulfil a promise, to offer an explanation about something to clarify an issue to supply a piece of information…
column2: Gbogbo àkùdè gbólóhùn  Àlàmú yìí níí ṣe pẹ̀lú lílọ sí ibìkan láti lọ rí ẹnìkan láti lọ mú ìlérí kan ṣe tàbí láti lọ ṣàlàyé nǹkan tàbí láti wá ojútùú sí ọ̀rọ̀ kan  tàbí  láti ta wọ́n lólobó nípa nǹkan...

column1: Alamu had opened himself up to suspicion! He had questions to answer!
column2: Àlàmú ti tú ara rẹ̀ fó! Ó ní ìbéèrè láti dáhùn.

column1: Labake remembered only two occasions when she fought Alamu over secret lovers, but that was in London.
column2: Làbákẹ́ rántí ẹ̀ẹ̀méjì péré tí ó ti bá Àlàmú jà nípa olólùfẹ́ ìkọ̀kọ̀, ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí wọ́n wà ní Lọ́ńdọ́ọ̀nù ni èyí.

column1: First, it was on account of Josephine, the Jamaican professional belly dancer based in London.
column2: Lákọ̀ọ́kọ́, nítorí Josephine ọmọ ìlú Jàmáíkà, tí ó jẹ́ ògbólógbòó afikùnjó nílùú Lọ́ńdọ́ọ̀nù.

column1: Labake had accompanied Alamu to the theatre at Leicester Square in London to watch Josephine perform that day. It was a good show. Graceful Josephine wriggled her shapely hips seductively, to the rhythmof the tom-tom, trumpet and the cymbal – to the admiration of the audience. Alamu was particularly excited.
column2: Làbákẹ́ sin Àlàmú lọ sí tíátà ní gbàgede Luchester láti lọ wòran ijó rẹ̀. Ó jẹ́ ìran tó dùn-ún wò. Josephine jó ijo náàdáadáa tó wú àwọn ènìyàn lórí. Inú  Àlàmú dùn yàtọ̀ sí ti àwọn èrò ìwòran yòókù.

column1: Labake looked at Alamu and saw in his eyes a slow burn of passion for Josephine and she had warned him there and then to take his time – to play it cool. Shye had thought that the end of it all – that the matter had been laid to rest.
column2: Làbákẹ́ wo Àlàmú lójú, ó sì rí ìfẹ́ Josephine lójú rẹ̀, ó sì kìlòfún un lójú ẹsẹ̀. Ó sì ti rò ó wí pé Àlàmú ti gbọ́ràn.

column1: But at a latter day, Labake retrieved three of Josephine’s pictures from inside the breast pocket of Alamu’s coat… Then there was the day Labake caught him alone with Josephine at the park.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn ìgbà náà, Làbákẹ́ rí àwòrán Josephine mẹ́ta nínú àpò àyà aṣọ Àlàmú. Lọjọ́ míì ń Làbákẹ́ ká a ní ọgbà iṣẹ́re pẹ̀lú ọmọbìnrin náà.

column1: For one whole week a cold war raged between Alamu and Labake. But finally, they made up.
column2: Fún ọsẹ kan gbáko, ogun tútù wáyé láàárín Àlàmú pẹ̀lú Làbákẹ́. ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n parí ẹ̀ nígbẹ̀yìn gbẹ́yín.

column1: The next quarrel with Alamu was over Caroline, a law student from Kenya.
column2: Aáwọ̀ mìíràn tó tún wáyé láàárín wọn wáyé nítorí Caroline, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀-òfin láti ìlú Kẹ́ńyà.

column1: She caught them at Trafalgar Square in the heart of London, playing with pigeons and taking photographs below the giant Nelson Statue!
column2: Làbákẹ́ káwọn ní gbàgede Trafalgar láàárín gùngùn ìlú Lọ́ńdọ́ọ̀nù, wọ́n ń fi ẹyẹlẹ́ ṣere tíwọ́n sì ń ya àwòrán lábẹ́ ère Nelson ńlá!

column1: She hailed on them from inside the city bus that was taking her across to Albany Street – letting them know they’d been caught.
column2: Ó ké sí wọn láti inú ọkọ̀-akéròìlú tí ó ń gbé e lọ sí òpópónà Albany, ó fẹ́ kí wọ́n mọ̀ pé òun ti ká wọn.

column1: Labake kept her cool until the time she saw both of them again at Hyde Park where they stood arm in arm, listening to the chattering of a public speaker at the Park corner.
column2: Làbákẹ́ kò bá a jà, àfi ìgbà tí ó tún rí àwọn méjèèjì ní ọgbà ìṣeré Hyde, ní bi tí wọ́n ti jọ dúró, tí wọ́n sì fọwọ́ kọ́ ara wọn lọ́rùn, tí wọn sì ń tẹ́tí sí sọ̀rọ̀-sọ̀rọ̀ kan tí ó ń sọ̀rọ̀ ní kọ̀rọ̀ ọgbà ìṣeré náà.

column1: Alamu had told Labake he was going for his lecture at College just at the time she caught him at the famous London Gossip Corner with Caroline. That day, hell was let loose.
column2: Àlàmú sì ti sọ fún Làbákẹ́ wí pé òun ń lọ fún ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní kọ́lẹ́ẹ̀jì ní déédé ásìkò yẹn. Ásìkò náàsì ni Làbákẹ́ ká a ní kọ̀rọ̀ ẹjọ́-wẹ́wẹ́ tí ó jẹ́ ìlúmọ̀ọ́ká nílùú Lọ́ńdọ́ọ̀nù pẹlu Caroline. Ní ọjọ́ náà, gbegede gbiná!

column1: And it seems the end of their association had come. But latter, again with the effective intervention of Alamu’s friends in London, everything was settled.
column2: Ó sì fẹ́ jọ ọ́ pé òpin ti dé bá ìbáṣepò wọn. ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tó yá, àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ Àlàmú nílùú Lọ́ńdọ́ọ̀nù dá sí ọ̀rọ̀ wọn, gbogbo rẹ̀ sì níì yanjú.

column1: That was England Labake reflected again…
column2: Làbákẹ́ tún sọjí pé ìlú Englandì nìyẹn…………………….

column1: Here in Nigeria there was nobody to supect except perhaps Alamu’s secretary. The secretary took her telephone call on two occasions. Her, ‘can I help you?’ expression on the phone irritated Labake so much.
column2: Níhìn-ín orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà, kò sí ẹni tí ó lè fura sí… bóyá akọ̀wé Àlàmú níbi iṣẹ́. Akọ̀wé yìí ti gbé ìpè rẹ̀ lẹ́ẹ̀mejì ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, ìbéèrè “kí ni mo lè ṣe fún un yín?” rẹ̀ lórí aago ìpè rí Làbákẹ́ lára púpọ̀.

column1: She had said it on those two occasion with a care-free, impudent  tone, and she didn’t  quite like it.
column2: Ọmọbìnrin  náà ti sọ èyí fún un pẹ̀lú ohùn àfojúdi àti àìbìkítà lẹ́ẹ̀mejì ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ náà, kò sì fẹ́ràn èyí.

column1: During the second telephone call, Labake wanted to shout back at the lady, ‘No! No! stop it! You can’t help me! Just give me my husband. Put me through to my husband quickly. And leave us to talk alone. Nothing more. You can’t help me lady!’
column2: Nígbà ìpè kejì ni Làbákẹ́ fẹ́ jágbe mọ́ ọn “Rárá Rárá! Dánu Dúró! O ò lè ràn mí lọ́wọ́! Ṣáàfún mi lọ́kọ mi. Gbé aago fún ọkọ mi kíá. Kí o sì fi wá sílẹ̀ kí a dá sọ̀rọ̀. Ó tán. O ò lè ràn mí lọ́wọ́ arábìnrin!

column1: Labake  had called at Alamu’s office one day. And that day, his messenger had told her  oga was busy inside and did not want to be disturbed. Busy doing what?  Labake had wondered.
column2: Làbákẹ́ tún lọ sí ọ́fíìsì Àlàmú lọ́jọ́ kan. Lọ́jọ́ náà ni ìráńṣẹ́ ọ́fíìsì Àlàmú sọ fún un pé “ọ̀gá ń ṣiṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́”, kò sì fẹ́ kí ẹnikẹ́ni dí i lọ́wọ́.  Làbákẹ́ ronú, kí ló lè máa ṣe?

column1: ‘Do let him know it’s Labake waiting to see him!’
column2: “Jẹ́ kí ó mọ̀ pé Làbákẹ́ ni ó fẹ́ rí i!”.

column1: Labake heard some muffled-tone whisperings coming from Alamu’s air-conditioned office and blood gushed inside her veins.
column2: Làbákẹ́ gbọ́ ohùn wẹ́rẹ́ – wẹ́rẹ́ tí ó ń jáde láti ọ́fíìsì Àlàmú tí ẹ̀rọ amúlétutù wà……..ẹ̀jẹ̀ sì rọ́ wọ inú iṣan rẹ̀.

column1: ‘Go and deliver my message to him,’ she said, almost shouting, ‘I am Mrs. Alamu Olaoye.’ The  messenger slipped inside his boss’s office and came out in another minute to tell Labake:
column2: “Lọ jíṣẹ́ fún un”, ó sọ̀rọ̀, ó fẹ́rẹ̀ é máa pariwo. “Èmi ni ìyáàfin  Àlàmú Ọláoyè”. Òjíṣẹ́ náà sáré wọlé láti lọ jíṣẹ́, ní ìṣẹ́jú mìíràn, ó jáde láti lọ sọ fún Làbákẹ́ pé;

column1: ‘Madam, oga say make you… make you… em… em… come in,’
column2: “Mọ̀mọ́, ọ̀gá ní kí ẹ ………kí ẹ ẹ̀m…ẹ̀m…….wọlé”.

column1: Labake cast one hateful look at the messenger and entered to find Alamu and his secretary in what seemed to her as tete-a-tete. The secretary was taking down some dictation to prepare an important official document. Labake’s  crimson eyeballs burnt the secretary down to ashes!
column2: Làbákẹ́ fi ojú burúkú wo òjí ṣẹ́ náà, ó sì wọlé, ó rí ọkọ rẹ̀ àti akọ̀wé ní ipò tí ó fu ú lára. Akọ̀wé náà ń ko àwọn àpèkọ kan sílẹ̀, láti ṣètò ìwé àṣírí ọ́fíìsì kan tí ó ṣe pàtàkì. ẹyin ojú Làbákẹ́ pípọ́ n sun akọ̀wé náà di eérú.

column1: And she listened, irritated, as Alamu whispered the instruction which the secretary scribbled down nodding her head and smilling.
column2: Ó sì ń tẹ́tí, pẹ̀lú ìnira bí, Àlàmú ṣe ń sọ àwọn àlàyé tí akọ̀wé náà ń kọ sílẹ̀ ní kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ tí akọ̀wé náà ń kanrí mọ́lẹ̀, tí ó sì ń rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́.

column1: Well…if there was one woman in Alamu’s life it might as well be ths damned secretary.
column2: Nítorí náà, bí ọmọbìnrin kan bá wà nínú ìgbésí ayé Àlàmú, ó lè jẹ́ akọ̀wé olórí burúkú yìí.

column1: Labake subjected herself to mental torture.
column2: Làbákẹ́ jọ̀wọ́ ara rẹ̀ fún ìpòruru ọpọlọ.

column1: She grew weary of the task and wanted to sleep.
column2: Iṣẹ́ náà ti ń sú u, ó sì fẹ́ sùn.

column1: But her head continued aching badly. The heavy snoring inside Alamu’s room came frightfully into her ears.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n orí ń fọ́ ọ gidi. Híhànrun wúwo láti inú yàrá Àlàmú ń jáde wá sí etí rẹ̀ tìbẹ̀rù-tìbẹ̀rù.

column1: It blasted the silence of the night like an open throttled lorry and crashed through Labake’s central nervous system like a chainsaw laying waste a forest.
column2: Dídún yìí borí ìdákẹ́ rọ́rọ́ òru bí i ọkọ̀ àjàgbé tí ìjánu rẹ̀ ti ṣí sílẹ̀, ó sì wọ Làbákẹ́ ní akínyẹmí ara bíi ayùn ẹlẹ́gbà tí ó ba igbó jẹ́.

column1: Alamu slept like a king in now, forcing all lesser mortals to stay awake!
column2: Àlàmú sùn falala nígbà tí ó fi tiẹ̀ dí gbogbo ayé lọ́wọ́!

column1: The solitary voice of the Imam came out loud over the loud-speaker early one morning, summoning all ‘servant of God’ to prayer.
column2: Ohùn ìmáàmù já geere lórí ariwo ẹ̀rọ amóhùndúngbẹ̀mù ní kùtùkùtù òwúrò ọjọ́ kan, tí ó ń pe àwọn ẹrú Ọlọ́run láti wá kírun.

column1: ‘Children of Ananbi wake up to worship Allah
column2: “Ẹ̀yin ọmọ Ànọ́bì ẹ dìde ń lẹ̀ kẹ́ẹ ké pe Allah

column1: And enter aljon-no
column2: Kí ẹ sì wọ Al-jọ́n-ń-nà

column1: The place of eternal peace and blessedness
column2: Ibi àlàáfíà àti ìbùkùn ayérayé

column1: But you children of Satan, sleep off like logs
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ẹ̀yin ọmọ àṣètán-ń-nì, ẹ sùn lọbí igi

column1: And be pushed like jaa-non-mo.
column2: Kí a sì tì yín sí Jáà-nọ́n-mọ̀

column1: The home of tears and everlasting sorrow’.
column2: Ilé ẹkún àti ìbànújẹ́ ayérayé”.

column1: At that time of the day, only a few people were usually ready to make the supreme effort to rise.
column2: Ní irú àsìk òyìí, àwọn ènìyàn díẹ̀ ni wọn ti máa ń gbaradì láti gbìyànjú àti dìde.

column1: Maybe ten per cent of all the adherents. And reluctantly too, these few would lumber awkwardly towards the various mosques in town – their eyelids still heavy with sleep.
column2: Bóyá ìdá mẹ́wàá nínú ọgọ́rùn-ún àwọn ẹlẹ́sìn náà. Pẹ̀lú ìlọ́ra ni àwọn díẹ̀ wọ̀nyí á fi ìnira wọ́ dé àwọn mọ́ṣáláṣí tí ó wà nílùú - pẹ̀lú ìpéǹpéjú wọn tí ó ṣì wúwo fún oorun.

column1: The rest of the people – ‘logs’ were doomed! Meaning that there would be congestion right from the gates of jaa-non-mo to its innermost part, on the day of reckoning!
column2: Àwọn ènìyàn yòókù tí wọ́n sùn kalẹ̀bí igi ni ìparun dé bá! Èyí túmọ̀ sí pé ẹnu ibodè Jáà-nọ́n-mọ̀ ni èrò á ti kún fọ́fọ́ títí wọ inú lọ́hùn-ún, lọ́jọ́ ìdájọ́!

column1: The imam’s voice came out loud, piercing the stillness of the cold early morning air. Labake checked the time almost five… Yes five o’ clock.
column2: Ohùn ìmáàmù jáde dáadáa, ó sì gún ìdákẹ́rọ́rọ́ òwúrọ̀ kùtùkùtù tútù.  Làbákẹ́ wo aago………aago márùn-ún ti fẹ́rẹ̀ ẹ́ lù. Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni aago márùn-ún.

column1: That seemed the most appropriate time to talk to Alamu. To ask him a few questions. The best time to give him a thorough curtain lecture.
column2: Ó jọ àsìkò tí ó yẹ láti bá Àlàmú sọ̀rọ̀. Láti bi í ní àwọn ìbéèrè díẹ̀, àsìkò tí ó dára jù láti fún un ní ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ abẹ́lé tó péye.

column1: There was perfect quiet and tranquility everywhere in the house now. The only sound that came to Labake’s ears was that of the alarm clock slowly ticking away the seconds.
column2: Ìdákẹ́rọ́rọ́ tí ó péye ṣì wà nínú ilé báyìí. Ohun tí ó sì ń dún sí etí Làbákẹ́ ni ti aago ìdágìrì tí ó ń dún láti rọ́pò ìṣẹ́jú àáyá.

column1: Labake entered Alamu’s room without knocking – and got the the greatest shock of her life – Alamu was not around! The room was empty! She hastened to the bathroom and the toilet. There was no trace of her husband!
column2: Làbákẹ́ wọ yàrá Àlàmú láì kan lẹ̀kùn, ó sì rí ohun ìyálenu ìjayà tí ó tóbi jù láyé rẹ̀! Àlàmú kò sí ní ilé! Inú yàrá ṣófo! Ó sáré wọ inú ilé-ìwẹ̀ àti ilé-ìgbẹ́. Kò sí àmì pé ọkọ rẹ̀ wà nítòsí!

column1: The car park was empty Labake stood transfixed for a moment not knowing what else to do…
column2: Ọgbà ìgbọ́kọ̀-sí ti ṣófo. Làbákẹ́ dúró tìyanu-tìyanu fún ìgbà díẹ̀, láìmọ ohun tí ó fẹ́ ṣe………………………….

column1: Yesterday night she remembered, she bid her husband good night before going to sleep. Alamu had nodded his head in answer and soon she heard the grating noise of the door lock – then, his snoring…
column2: Ní alẹ́ àná, ó rántí pé òun kí ọkọ òun pé “ó dàárò” kí ó tó lọ sùn. Àlàmú sì kanrí mọ́lẹ̀ ní ìdáhùn tí ó sì gbọ́ dídún bí ó ṣe ń ti ilẹ̀kùn nígbàtí ó ṣe díẹ̀, nígbà tó sì yá, ohùn híhanrun rẹ̀ ló ń gbọ́.

column1: Now Alamu had gone out without letting her know his destination, his mission. And at suc odd hour of the day gone to some secret lover. ‘no doubt! The air was cold and chilly and the pang of jealousy that suddenly gripped Labake now made her desire the company of her husband more than ever before. The urge came to her rather spontaneously.
column2: Nísinsìnyí, Àlàmú  ti jáde láì dágbére, kò jẹ́ kí ó mọ èrò ọkàn rẹ̀. Láìsí àní-àní ọ̀dọ̀ olólùfẹ́ ìkọ̀kọ̀ rẹ̀ ni ó lọ ní àsìkò yẹn. Afẹ́fẹ́ òwúrọ̀ náà tutù, ìmí-ẹ̀dùn owú sì mú Làbákẹ́ lójijì tí ó sì wá ń ṣàfẹ́rí ọkọ rẹ̀ ju ti tẹ́lẹ̀ lọ. Ara rẹ̀ ń wà lọ́nà lemọ́lemọ́, láìlè mú u mọ́ra.

column1: She imagined her husband in gthe warm embrace of his secret lover this cold morning, she swallowed some saliva. But that was not the issue now.
column2: Ó ń ro bí ọkọ rẹ̀ ṣe ma máa dì mọ́ olólùfẹ́ ìkọ̀kọ̀ rẹ̀ ní òwúrọ̀ tútù yìí, ó sì gbé itọ́ mì. ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe ohun tó ṣe kókó nìyẹn.

column1: Labake went back into her lonely room. Lonely now to her even with little Tinu’s presence in the room! She waited patiently. This incident had given Alamu an additional question to answer.
column2: Làbákẹ́ padà sí yàrá rẹ̀ tó dá wà. Ìdáwà yìí pọ̀ tóbẹ́ẹ̀ pẹ̀lú bí Tinú kékeré ṣe wà nínú yàrá! Ódúró pẹ̀lú sùúrù. Ìṣẹ́le yìí ti fi kún àwọn ìbéèrè ti Àlàmú  ní láti dáhùn sí.

column1: Later in the morning that day at about ten o’ clock, Labake heard the sound of Alamu’s car. ‘Soon Alamu himself was knocking at the door. Anxiously, Labake made  for the door and saw that Alamu was not alone. There were two other men in his company. They followed closely behind him as he entered the house.
column2: Nígbà tí ilẹ̀ mọ́ dáadáa lọ́jọ́ náà ni nǹkan bíi aago mẹ́wàá, Làbákẹ́ gbọ́ ohùn ọkọ̀ ayọ́kẹ́lẹ́ Àlàmú . Nígbà tó ṣe díè, Àlàmú fún rarẹ̀ ti ń kan ilẹ̀kùn. Pẹ̀lú ara gbígbọ̀n,  Làbákẹ́ lọ sí ẹnu ọ̀nà, ó sì rí i pé Àlàmú  nìkan kọ́ ló wà ní bẹ̀. Àwọn Ọkùnrin méjì mìíràn wàpẹ̀lú rẹ̀. Wọ́n ń súnmọ́ ọn típẹ́típẹ́ bí ó ṣe ń wọ inú ilé.

column1: Labake threw a questioning glance at Alamu. Then transferred her puzzled gaze to the two men who accompanied him. The two men shot back their own glances, impudently, at Labake. Labake hated them at once.
column2: Làbákẹ́ wo Àlàmú  pẹ̀lú ẹ̀mí ìbéèrè. Lẹ́yìn náà ni ó gbé ojú rẹ̀ kúrò tí ó kọjú sí àwọn Ọkùnrin méjì tí ó sìn ín wọlé pẹ̀lú ìrújú. Àwọn ọkùnrin méjì náà dá wíwò Làbákẹ́ padà pẹ̀lú àfojúdi fún un. Lẹ́sẹ̀ kan náà, ni Làbákẹ́ kórira wọn.

column1: These were the typical men of the city. Men one should be careful of interacting with - hefty, big- chested and heavy-muscled.
column2: Àwọn Ọkùnrin yìí ni ọmọ ìgboro ìlú. Àwọn Ọkùnrin tí ènìyàn gbọ́dọ̀ ṣọ́ra láti máa bá ṣe– wọ́n tóbi, wọ́n fẹ̀ láyà, wọ́n sì ní iṣan.

column1: Yes. The typical city men. The type who sweat hard, pounding furiously at iron rod on the anvils, and energetically fanning embers out at furnaces with the bellows inside their shops - if they were blacksmiths or goldsmiths.
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni. Àwọn ọkùnrin ìgboro ìlú. Irú àwọn tí wọ́n máa ń la òógùn líle nígbà  tíwọ́n bá ń gún irin nínú ṣọ́ọ̀bù tí wọ́n bá jẹ́ alágbẹ̀dẹ tàbí alágbẹ̀dẹ wúrà.

column1: The type of men who drive heavy trailers and tankers from Ibadan to Kano and Maiduguri in the far North, with hired harlots for company.
column2: Irú àwọn Ọkùnrin tí wọ́n ń wa ọkọ̀ àjàgbé ẹlẹ́rù wúwo àti táńkà epo-rọ̀bì láti Ìbàdàn sí Kánò àti Màìdúgùríní àríwá jíjìn pẹ̀lú àwọn obìnrin alágbèrè tí wọn á sanwó fún láti sìn wọ́n lọ.

column1: The type who justle their taxi-cabs, bolekaja and danfo buses about the busy streets of the town, blaring their horns ceaselessly, adding to the already chaotic pandemonium of the city, The type who wear dirty tarpaulin overalls at the open mechanic workshops, holding chisels, spanners, bolts, screwdrivers - reeking of brake - fluid and engine-oil.
column2: Irú àwọn ọkùnrin yìí ni wọ́n ń wa ọkọ̀ kabú-kabú, bọ́lẹ̀kájà tàbí dáńfó wọn káàkiri òpópón àtí wọ́n ń dá kún ìṣòro ariwo ìgbòkè-gbodò ìlú, irú àwọn ọkùnrin yìí ni wọ́n ń wọ aṣọ tapolíìnì dídọ̀tí ní gbàdede ṣọ́ọ̀bù àwọn atọ́kọ̀ṣe, wọ́n á wá di àwọn ohun èèlò ìrìn bíi ṣísúùlù, sípánà, bóòtù àti irinṣẹ́ ìtúbóòtù, pẹ̀lú òórùn òróró búréèkì àti ẹ̀rọ ọkọ.

column1: Yes, the type of men who, after the labour of the day, would come out in the evening wearing neat dresses sprinkled with heavy perfume, and who would wriggle hips to the rhythm of fuji music, under the glittering fluorescent lights in the barber's shop or in front of the record stores along city streets – making passes at the city girls who walked past….
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, irú àwọn ọkùnrin tíwọn á múra dáadáa, tíwọn á sì fín òórùn dídùn sára lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n bá ti siṣẹ́ àṣekára ọjọ́ náà tán, wọn á wá máa jùrù sí orin fújì lábẹ́ iná dídán níwájú ṣọ́ọ̀bù onígbàjámọ̀ tàbí níwájú ile-ìtàjà rẹ́ kọ́ọ̀dù lójúòpópón àìgboro – wọ́n á wá dẹnu ìfẹ́ kọ àwọn ọmọbìnrin ìgborotó bá rìn kọjá……………

column2: Àkókò yìí ni àwọn ògbólógbòó ọlọ́ṣà ń wá sí ilé ní ojúmọmọ, wọ̣n á kọ́kọ́ ṣe ara wọn lálejò pẹ̀lú ìgò otí tí ó bá wà nínú ẹ̀rọ amómitutù yín kí ó tó di wí pé wọ́n kò sí “iṣẹ́” tíwọ́n wá ṣe.

column1: The period when robbers would snap their fingers asking you to surrender the keys and particulars of your vehicle or face an unpalatable, instant consequence.

column2: Èyí ni àsìkò tí àwọn ògbólógbòó ọlọ́ṣà á pè láti kéde ọjọ́ àti àsìkò tí wọ́n ń bọ̀ láti wá “kí i yín”, wọ́n á kọ lẹ́tà pé kí o gbaradì láti gba àlejò àwọn, wọ́n sì lè tún sọ iye àlejò tí ẹ ó máa retí!

column1: The age when robbers faced the firing squad at the Polo Ground beaming with smiles and waving the crowd goodbye, asking the people to cheer up and take good care of themselves!

column1: Alamu's mother crashed to the floor, and burst into a body-racking sob! It was convulsive. It was prolonged. She did not recover from the shock until after some five minutes. When at last she regained consciousness, it was still with the ‘why-why-why.. what what-what. and how-how-how’ questions on her lips.

column1: Was this the child sucked her breasts for three years and over whom she had countless sleepless nights? Had her only son now gone mad? Was this the reason why her breasts twitched and twitched for seven days. twitching because Alamu had started to turn his head?

column1: There was only one small entrance to Esuniyi’s asylum and inside it, the herbalist planted the shady odan trees, numbering up to twelve stands.
column2: Ẹnu ọ̀nà kékeré kan ló wọ ọgbà ìtọ́jú wèrè Èṣùníyì yìí, nínú rẹ̀ ni oníṣègùn  náà gbin igi ọdán bí i méjìlá tó ṣíji bo ibẹ̀sí.

column1: There were three mud buildings which housed about twenty inmates of the asylum. These inmates were always yelping and letting hell loose on the surrounding villages.
column2: Ilé alámọ̀ mẹ́ta ni ó wà níbẹ̀, tí ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan sì gbà tó ogún aláágànàá. Wọ́n máa ń pariwo tí wọ́n sì ń farani àwọn ìlú tó yí wọn ká.

column1: In a quick flash, the picture of Esuniyi, came in hand, and a ferocious look on his face, came to Mama.
column2: Ní kíákíá, àwòrán Èṣùníyì pẹ̀lú ẹgba lọ́wọ́ àti ìwò ìrorò lójú rẹ̀ wá sórí Màmá.

column1: She saw Esuniyi sweating, his eyes bulging and his whip mercilessly circling round the bodies of those stubborn ones who would not obey his instructions.
column2: Ó rí i tí Èṣùníyì ń làágùn, tí ojú rẹ̀ràn tí àtòrì rẹ̀ sì ń dá sẹ̀ríà sí ara àwọn aláìgbọràn tí kò tẹ̀lé àṣẹ rẹ̀.

column1: ‘Stop! Stop that noise!’ Mama imagined Esuniyi shouting.
column2: “Dákẹ́! Dákẹ́ ariwo yẹn!” Màmá ń rò ó bí Èṣùníyì tí ṣe ń pariwo.

column1: ‘Remain standing where you are!’ ‘Alright, it is time for food.
column2: “Dúró sibí tí o wà! Ó dáa, àsìkò oúnjẹ rè é.

column1: And you are all going to take the food sitting down on that wooden bench in the open yard.
column2: Gbogbo yín sì máa gba oúnjẹ  náà lórí ìjokòó lórí àga onígi tó wà nínú àgbàlá.

column1: Not standing up like that... You hear me! You! Why are you still standing to eat your food?
column2: Kì í ṣe lórí ìdúró bá yẹn…. O gbọ́ mi! Ìwọ! Kílódé tí ó ṣì ń dúró jẹun?”

column1: Didn’t you hear my instruction?’
column2: “Ṣé o ò gbọ́ àṣẹ mi ni?”

column1: Wham! Wham! Wham! Mama imagined Esuniyi’s whip circling round the body of two of his patients.
column2: “Wàmù!Wàmù!Wàmù!” Màmá ń rò ó bí pàṣán Èṣùníyì ṣe ń dún lára àwọn aláìsàn rẹ̀ méjì.

column1: They quickly sat down on the wooden bench along with the others and continued eating their food, eyeing their master in fear.
column2: Kíá ni wọ́n jókòó lórí àga onígi náà pẹ̀lú àwọn yóòkú wọ́n tí wọ́n sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí jẹ oúnjẹ wọn, tí wọn ń wojú onítọ́ọ̀jú wọn tìbẹ̀rù-tìbẹ̀rù.

column1: Mama opened her eyes briefly and heaved a sigh. In another minute she closed them again - and other images came crowding into her memory....
column2: Láìfa ọ̀rọ̀ gùn, Màmá lajú, ó sì mí àmíkàn. Ní ìṣẹ́jú mìíràn, ó tún pa ojú dé àwọn àwòrán mìíràn tún wá sí orí rẹ̀…….

column1: Evening time in the asylum.... Mama saw, in her mind’s eye, Esuniyi shaving the bushy hair of some of his patients.
column2: Ní ọwọ́ ìrọ̀lẹ́ nínú ọgbà ìtọ́jú….. màmá tún fi ojú inú ọkàn rẹ̀ rí Èṣùníyì níbi tí ó ti ń fá irun tó kún bí igbó tó wà lórí aláìsàn rẹ̀.

column1: Mama imagined herself holding Alamu by the handd, leading him to Esuniyi’s asylum with tears in her eyes. And Esuniyi rushing out of his house with a whip to meet them.
column2: Màmá rò ó bí òun ṣe fa Àlàmú lọ́wọ́, tí ó sì ń mú u lọ sí ọgbà ìtọ́jú Èṣùníyì pẹ̀lú omijé lójú. Àti bí Èṣúńiyì ṣe ń sáré bọ̀ níta láti pàdé e wọn pẹ̀lú pàsán lọ́wọ́.

column1: In a minute, he was lashing out at Alamu with the long whip, beating him to submission, beating sense into his head to let him know he was in a house, a special house, where he had to conform...
column2: Láàárín ìṣẹ́jú kan, ó ti ń kó o bo Àlàmú, tí ó ń nàá kí ara rẹ̀ lè balẹ̀, tí ó ń na ọgbọ́n sínú orí rẹ̀ kí ó lè mọ̀ pé inú ilé, ilé ọ̀tọ̀ tí ara rẹ̀ ti níláti balẹ̀ ní ó wà….

column1: Next she saw Esuniyi shaving Alamu’s own head and then chaining his hands and feet.
column2: Lẹ́yìn èyí, ó tún rí i tí Èṣùníyì fá irun orí Àlàmú tí ó sì fi sẹkẹ́sẹkẹ̀ dè é tọwọ́ tẹsẹ̀.

column1: That was where she would take her son, to get his present problem solved.
column2: Ibẹ̀ ni á mú ọmọ rẹ̀ lọ, láti rí i pé ìṣòro rẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ lọ́wọ́ yìí yanjú.

column1: And she knew too well that the problem would be solved there in a matter of weeks.
column2: Ó sì mọ̀ dáadáa pé ìṣòro náà áníyanjú lááàrín ọ̀sẹ̀ mélòó kan.

column1: Esuniyi was a master of his art. Mama had witnessed how he had solved three of such problems for the villagers....
column2: Èṣúńiyì mọ̀ iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ dunjú. Màmá tirí bí ó ṣe yanjú irú ìṣòro bẹ́ẹ̀ mẹ́ta ní abúlé .…

column1: And how his name was, consequently, on the lips of all the inhabitants of the one hundred and fifty villages of the district...
column2: Àti bí wọ́n ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í jẹ orúkọ rẹ̀ lẹ́nu láàrin àwọn olùgbé abúlé bí i àádọ̀jọ tí ó wà ní agbègbè náà…..

column1: Yes, Esuniyi cured the man from Kange... The young woman from Akokura, whom he later married...
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, Èṣùníyì wo ọkùnrin ará Kange sàn, àti ọmọbìnrin tí ó wá láti Akókurà tí ó padà fẹ́…….

column1: He restored the violent body from Jooda to normalcy. There were other cases Mama could not immediately remember.
column2: Ó mú ara Jooda tí kò balẹ̀ padà bọ̀ sípò. Àwọn ìwòsàn mìíràn tí Màmá kò lè rántí ní kíákíá.

column1: Esuniyi’s aslylum was surrounded by a strange aura.
column2: Àwọn ẹ̀mí àìrí kan ni ó yí ọgbà ìtọ́jú Èṣùníyì ká.

column1: You would see him pounding something inside the morter, grinding something on the stone, chewing, boiling and burning one thing or the other.
column2: Wà á rí i níbi tí ó ti ń gún nǹkankan lódó, à lọ nǹkankan lórí ọlọ, á jẹ́ nǹkan lẹ́nu, á bọ nǹkankan tàbí kí ó jó nǹkan mìíràn.

column1: He would preserve the hair of his patients for medicinal purposes.
column2: Á tọ́jú irun orí àwọn aláìsán rẹ̀ tí ó fáfún ìṣègùn.

column1: Burn part of the hair, mix it with some herb and an oily substance, pour it back on the shaved heads and his patients and start reciting incantation for each one of them...
column2: Á jó lára rẹ̀, á pò ó pọ̀ mọ́ àwọn ewé àti nǹkan ọlọ́ràá kan, á wá dà á padà sí orí àwọn aláìsàn rẹ̀ tí ó ti fá yìí, á wá bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí pọfọ̀ fún wọn lọ́kọ́ọ̀kan….

column1: That was calling on the invisible power to enter the patients’ heads,  cool down their brain and restore normalcy to them.
column2: Èyí tí ó túmọ̀ sí pípe agbára àìrí kan láti wọ orí àwọn aláìsàn náà, kí ó mú ọpọlọ wọn wálẹ̀, kí ó sì mú wọn bọ̀ sípò padà.

column1: In the dead of the night he would chant special incantations against the enemies of his patients. The effect was usually dramatic.
column2: Ní òru ọ̀gànjọ́, á pe àwọn ọfọ̀ ọ̀tọ̀ kan láti tako àwọn ọ̀tá àwọn aláìsàn rẹ̀. Isẹ́ òog̀un yìí sì máa ń dàbí i eré.

column1: One by one the enemies were usually made to suffer for their atrocities. You would see them committing suicide by hanging on the tall araba or the iroko; you would see them plunging head-long into river or crawling on their knees to Esuniyi to beg for forgiveness.
column2: Lọ́kọ̀ọ̀kan ni àwọn ọ̀tá náà máa jìyà ẹ̀sẹ̀ wọn. Wà á rí wọn níbi tí wọn tí pa ara wọn bí i kí wọ́n lọ so ara wọn kọ́ sórí igi ìrókò tàbí kí wọ́n rì sómi tàbí kí wọ́n máa wọ́ pẹ̀lú orúnkún wọn tí wọ́n sì ń tọrọ ìdàríjì lọ́dọ̀ Èṣùníyì.

column1: Mama now looked at Labake, the way one looks at the stinking rubbish inside the rubbish pit and silently cursed her.
column2: Màmá tún wo Làbákẹ́, tìkà-tẹ̀gbin …….

column1: She raised up her head and saw Labake holding her son’s hand inside the picture hanging on the wall of the sitting room and smiling. A treacherous smile on the face of a devil!
column2: Ó gbójú sókè, ó sì rí fọ́tò Làbákẹ́ tí ó di ọwọ́ ọmọ rẹ̀ mú tí ó sì rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́ lára ògiri yàrá ìgbàlejò wọn. Ẹ̀rín ìyàngì lójú èṣù.

column1: All through the previous day when Mama confronted Labake, Alamu was not in. He went out to town and did not come back until late in the night when everybody had gone to sleep.
column2: Ní gbogbo ìgbà tí Màmá dojúkọ Làbákẹ́ lánàá, Àlàmú  kò sí nílé. Ó lọ sí ìgboro kò sì dé bọ̀rọ̀, ilẹ̀ ti ṣú púpọ̀ nígbà tí ó dé, tí gbogbo ènìyàn sì ti lọ sùn.

column1: Quietly, he had sneaked inside, locked the door on himself and soon was snoring.
column2: Ó yọ́ kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ wolé, ó sì ti ìlẹ̀kùn mọ́ ara rẹ̀, tí ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í hanrun láìpẹ́.

column1: He woke up late in the morning to discover that Mama had thing inside her basket in preparation for the return journey to the district.
column2: Ó pẹ́ láàárọ̀ kí ó tó jí, kí ó sì tó rí i wí pé Màmá ti múra, ó sì ti ń di apẹ̀rẹ̀ rẹ̀ ní ìmúra sílẹ̀ láti padà lọ sí abúlé.

column1: Then he saw also that his breakfast was ready on the table.
column2: Ó sì tún rí i  wí pé oúnjẹ òwúrọ̀ rẹ̀ ti wà lórí tábílì.

column1: He looked at his mother for a moment and turned his eyes to the food on the table the next minute. He seemed to be undecided... Well, there was no need for any hurry on the part of Mama.
column2: Ó wo ìyá rẹ̀ díẹ̀, ó sì tún yíjú sí tábìlì ibi tí oúnjẹ wà ó jọ wí pé kò ì tí ì pinnu èyí tó fẹ́ ṣe…. Kò sí ìdí fún un láti kánjú ní ti Màmá.

column1: He could talk to her after food. So, Alamu took his seat at table.
column2: Ó lè bá wọn sọ̀rọ̀ lẹ́yìn oúnjẹ. Fún ìdí èyí, Àlàmú jókòó sídìí tábìlì.

column1: Before Mama ever had the time to raise up her head, the first two spoonfuls of rice had disappeared inside Alamu’s tummy!
column2: Kí Màmá tó ráyè gbórí sókè, ṣíbí ìrẹsì méjì ti wọ ikùn rẹ̀.

column1: And when Mama suddenly jumped up from her seat and said,
column2: Nígbà náà ni màmá déédé fò sókè lórí ìjókòó rẹ̀ tí ó ní,

column1: ‘Alamu! Alamu! I want to talk to you.... before your meal!... before your meal’ - it was too late!The third spoon of rice was well ion its way down Alamu’s throat.
column2: “Àlàmú! Àlàmú! Mo fẹ́ báọ sọ̀rọ̀…..kí ó tó jẹun!.....kí o tó jẹun!” - Óti pẹ́ jù, ṣíbí ìrẹsì kẹ́ta ti wà lọ́nà ọ̀fun Àlàmú.

column1: What was left for Mama to do was to move to the table and examine the soup in front of her son.
column2: Nǹkan tí ó kù fún Màmá láti ṣe ni kí ó lọ sídìí tábìlì kí ó sì ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ọbẹ̀ tí ó wà níwájú rẹ̀.

column1: Egusi soup... Yes... But with some blackish substance inside it.
column2: Ọbẹ̀ Ẹ̀gúsí…. Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni….. pẹ̀lú àwọn nǹkan dúdúdúdú nínú rẹ̀.

column1: Her keen eyes saw it.
column2: Ojú rẹ̀ mu, ó sì rí i.

column1: The type Zenabu talked about.
column2: Irú àwọn èyí ti Sènábù ń sọ.

column1: Alamu glanced back strangely at his mother.
column2: Àlàmú padà wo ìyá rẹ̀ ní ìwò tó ṣàjèjì.

column1: Why all these fuss over egusi soup?
column2: Kí ni gbogbo ìrọ̀kẹ̀kẹ̀ yìí, lórí ọbẹ̀ ẹ̀gúsí lásán?

column1: ‘What is this you are eating Alamu?’
column2: “Kí ni èyí tí ò ń jẹ́ yìí Àlàmú?”

column1: The old woman asked - rather unnecessarily, but nonetheless meaningfully.
column2: Ìyá àgbà náà bèèrè - ìbéèrè tí kò nílò, ṣúgbọ̀n tí ó nítumọ̀ sí i.

column1: ‘I mean this?’
column2: “Èyí ni mò ń sọ?”

column1: ‘Soup Mama’. Alamu laughed - the usual prolonged, full-throated laugh which two days ago left tears trickling down Mama’s cheeks. Mama moaned.
column2: “ Ọbẹ̀ ni Màmá ”, Àlàmú  rẹ́rìn-ín bí ó ti máa ń rín-in, irú èyí tí ó rín níjẹta tí ó fa kí Màmá bú sẹ́kún. Màmá gbin.

column1: ‘Alamu... Alamu... Are you sure this is ordinary soup?’
column2: “Àlàmú… Àlàmú… ṣé ó dá ọ lójú pé ọbẹ̀ lásán ni èyí?

column1: ‘Yes. Just soup Mama... Good soup. What else?’
column2: “Bẹ́ẹ̀ni. Ọbẹ̀ ni Màmá… Ọbẹ̀ tó dára. Kí ló kù?”,

column1: Mama gave the plate of soup a hard, suspicious stare and shook her head.
column2: Màmá wo abọ́ ọbẹ̀  náà ní ìwò tó le, tí ó sì mú ìfura dání.

column1: Yes... That black substance again. She saw it clearly - sprinkled all over the egusi soup...
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ni……kiní dúdú yẹn tún ní. Ó rí i dáadáa - tí wọ́n wọ́nọn sórí ọbẹ̀ ègúsí náà...

column1: Was Alamu blind? Surely he has been charmed... Was Alamu’s nostrils blocked?
column2: Ṣe ojú Àlàmú fọ́ ni? Dájúdájú wọ́n ti sàsí i…… ṣé ihò imú Àlàmú dí ni?

column1: Mama cast a strange look at her son... Alamu continued to eat the rice and his mouth worked greedily.
column2: Màmá tún wo ọmọ rẹ̀ kòòró... Àlàmú ń bá oúnjẹ rẹ̀ lọ ní jíjẹ, ẹnu rẹ̀ sì ń ṣe wọ̀mùwọ̀mù.

column1: Mama heard the sound of his mouth and felt some pain - some sharp pain - inside her throat.
column2: Màmá ń gbọ́ ohùn ẹnu Àlàmú bí ó ṣe ń dún, ọ̀nà ọ̀fun rẹ̀ sì dùn ún púpọ̀.

column1: Alamu washed his rice down with water and noisily, continued munching on and on....
column2: Àlàmú fi omi ti ìrẹsì rẹ̀ lọ sínú, ó sì tẹ̀síwájú pẹ̀lú oúnjẹ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú dídún ẹnu rẹ̀...

column1: What would he not eat? There was nothing Labake gave him that he would not eat!
column2: Kí ni kò lè jẹ́? Kò sí nǹkan kí nǹkan tí Làbákẹ́ fún un tí kò lè jẹ!

column1: If she prepared a bowl of excreta for him as food, Alamu would take it with relish and satisfaction.
column2: Bí ó bá se abọ́ ìgbọ̀nṣẹ̀ kan fún un bi oúnjẹ, Àlàmú  á jẹ ẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìgbádùn àti ìtẹ̀lọ́rùn.

column1: If she gave him animal urine for water, Alamu would accept it and gulp it down his throat thirstily - and even thank her for it!
column2: Bí ó bá gbé ìtọ̀ ẹranko fún  un gẹ́gẹ́ bí omi Àlàmú  á gbàá, á sì gbé e mì tòùngbẹ tòùngbẹ - á sì tún dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀ fún un.

column1: Who would save him now? None but Esuniyi...
column2: Ta ni yóò wá gbàálà báyìí? Kò sẹ́lòmíràn àfi Èṣúńiyì…

column1: Esuniyi to the rescue! Delay could be dangerous.
column2: Èṣùníyì ló lè gbà á! Ìjáfara léwu.

column1: Alamu might soon take to the streets!
column2: Àlàmú mà lè já sí títì láìpẹ́!

column1: Mama grabbed her basket and stumbled out of the house.
column2: Màmá ki apẹ̀rẹ̀ rẹ̀ mọ́lẹ̀ ó sì sá kúrò nínú ílé.

column1: She knew that in a matter of days she would have to be back in town again to fetch Alamu.
column2: Ó mọ̀ pé láàrin ọjọ́ mélòó kan, òun á ní láti padà wá sí ìgboro láti mú Àlàmú.

column1: There should be no delay at all.
column2: Kò gbọdọ̀ jáfara rárá.

column1: The task before her was a task that must be accomplished - with dispatch.
column2: Iṣẹ́ kíákíá ló wà níwáju rẹ̀.

column1: As the days rolled by, Alamu sank deeper and deeper into own private world. So much so that Labake feared that her husband was soon going to go completely deaf and dumb - these in addition to the already heavy load of problems he was carrying on his shoulder. Some time ago, he had time to say one or two words in response to questions or requests from people, but not any longer.
column2: Bí ọjọ́ ṣe ń gorí ọjọ́, Àlàmú túbọ̀ ń rì sínú ayé àdáwà rẹ̀. Ó pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí Làbákẹ́ bẹ̀rù pé ọkọ òun á di odi àti adíti, èyí á wá kún ẹrù ìṣòro wúwo tó ti wà léjìká rẹ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀. Nígbà díẹ̀ sẹ́yìn, ó máa ń ráyè láti fèsì pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀ kan tàbí méjì sí ìbèèrè tí wọn bá bi í, ṣùgbọ́n kò rí bẹ́è mọ́.

column1: If anybody hissed now, Alamu no longer took notice; if anybody grumbled Alamu no more listened; if Labake shouted protests over cigarette he was smoking or the beer he was drinking, more frequently now than ever before, Alamu no longer cared.
column2: Bí ẹnìkan bá pòṣé nísìnyí, Àlàmú ò ṣàkíyèsí mọ́; bí ẹnikẹ́ni bá kùn, Àlàmú kò tẹ́tí mọ́; bí Làbákẹ́ bá ń tẹnumọ́ ìkìlọ̀ rẹ̀ lórí sìgá tí ó ń fà  tàbí  ọtí tí ó ń mu léraléra ju ti tẹ́lẹ̀ lọ, kò kan Àlàmú mọ́.

column1: Wading through the pyramid of files which he kept on top of an old cupboard in his room seemed now to be his main pre-occupation. He would bury his head inside the files for hours and leaf through their pages hastily ans anxiously. Then, pile the files up on the table by his side. Look away and heave a sigh. A few minutes later, he would go back, all over again, to the business of checking and rechecking the files, packing and re-packing them, arranging and re-arranging them. There was no end to it! At times, he would tear off a sheet or two from a particular file, read through it pointing to some sections of it with his forefinger and shaking his head, apparently as he stumbled on something that caught his interest.
column2: Wíwo òkìtì àwọn fáìlì tí ó tọ́jú sókè kọ́bọ́ọ̀dù àtijọ́ kan nínú yàrá rẹ̀ wá di iṣẹ́fún  un. A máa wo àwọn ìwé náàfún wákàtí púpọ̀, á sì tún máa ṣí àwọn ìwé náà láwẹ́láwẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìkánjú àti àníyàn. Lẹ́yìn náà á to àwọn ìwé náà jọ léra wọn sórí tábìlì ẹ̀gbẹ́ rẹ̀. Á gbójú kúrò á sì mí kanlẹ̀. Lẹ́yìn ìsẹ́jú díẹ̀, á padà sórí àwótúnwò fáìlì àti àkọtúnkọ pẹ̀lú àtòtúntò fáìlì wọ̀nyí. Kò sí òpin fún  èyí! Nígbà mìíràn, á ya ojú ewé kan kúrò nínú ìwé náà, á wá máa ka àwọn ìpín kan pẹ̀lú ìka ìlábẹ̀ rẹ̀, á má a mirí, àgàgà tí ó bá bá nǹkan tí ó wùú pàdé níbẹ̀.

column1: He suddenly had converted his own room into the big office of a self-styled Business Executive. Except that here he was his own Managing Director, his own Accountant, Auditor, Executive Officer, Typist and Messenger! It was another strange turn of events!
column2: Ó ti déédé sọ yárà rẹ̀ di ọ́fíìsí ńlá tí a dáfún ìlò ara rẹ̀. Yàtọ̀ sí pé òun ni adarí pátápátá fún ara rẹ̀, Òun ni asírò owó fún ara rẹ̀, òun tún ni ayẹ̀wé-owó-wò, ọ̀gá pátápátá, àtẹ̀wé àti ìránsẹ́ ọ́fíìsì fún rarẹ̀! Eléyìí tún jẹ́ àyípadà kàyééfì.

column1: Whenever Alamu was not wading through the files, he would be busy sipping his beer, puffing at his cigarette. Now, he no longer vomited, and the cigarette smoke no longer entered into his eyes or made him cough.
column2: Bí Àlàmú kò bá sí nídì́í kí ó máa ṣíwèé lọ ṣíwèé bọ̀, á máa yọ́ ọtí rẹ̀ mu, yóò sì máa fín eruku sìgá rẹ̀. Kìí bì mọ́ báyìí, èéfín sìgá ò kó sí i lójú bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, kò sí mú un húkọ́ mọ́.

column1: But he retained his strange laughter, and the effect of the alcohol was still very much with him. Which was one reason why he used to boast to himself that he could drive his car all through the streets of Ibadan with his eyes closed and following the left-hand lane! He could drink six bottles of acid, all at once to quench his thirst! He could, with only two quick steps, descend the stair cases of a two-storey building and get down to its ground floor without any scratch!
column2: Sùgbọ́n ẹ̀rín àbàmì àláriwo rẹ̀ ṣì wà, isẹ́ ọtí kò sì kúrò lára rẹ̀. Èyí sì jẹ́ ìdí kan tí ó fi máa ń fọ́nnu pé òun lè wa ọkọ̀ ayọ́kẹ́lẹ́ rẹ̀ káàkiri gbogbo òpópónà Ìbàdàn tí òun bá díjú tí òun sì tẹ́lè ọ̀nà apá òsì! Ó lè mu ásíìdì ìgò mẹ́fà lẹ́ẹ̀kan láti pòùngbẹ! Ó lè fi ìgbésẹ̀ méjì bọ́lẹ̀ lórí àkàsọ̀ ilé alájà méjì, kí ò sì délẹ̀ láìfarapa!

column1: How was one going to talk to the deaf? Somebody who was stone deaf? Labake tried it several times and failed.
column2: Báwo ni ènìyàn ṣe fẹ́ bá adití sọ̀rọ̀? Ènìyàn tí etí rẹ̀ ti dí pa? Làbákẹ́ ti gbìyànjú láìmọye ìgbà ó sì ti kùnà.

column1: ‘This you must hear Alamu'
column2: Ó gbọ́dọ̀ gbọ́ èyí Àlàmú'

column1: ‘Yea - ha ha ha ha! Hum hum! Ha ha!'
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni- ha ha ha ! hun hun ! ha! ha!'

column1: ‘Something that is very much on my mind ...'
column2: Nǹkan tí ó ń gbé mi lọ́kàn ...'

column1: ‘My! Em em -hum hum hum! - ha ha ha ha!'
column2: Ẹm ẹm –mi hun hun hun – ha ha ha ha

column1: ‘Listen please Alamu ... The other day Mama came ...'
column2: Àlàmú  jọ̀wọ́ tẹ́tí ... Ní ọjọ́ yẹn tí Màmá wá ...'

column1: ‘Well - ha ha ha ha - hum hum - ha ha ha ha!’ - then a frozen and far-away look on his face!
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀-ha ha ha ha- hun hun – ha ha ha ha!' - Ìwò tí ó dí, tí ó sì jìnnà hàn lójú rẹ̀!

column1: Tears gathered inside Labake’s eyes, tears for Alamu, tears for what she suffered at the hands of Alamu’s mother. How was Alamu going to know her ordeal? How was he going to know about the way his mother raved and raged? And then, those vicious accusations! Who was now going to vindicate her? She bottled all these up inside her mind. There was nobody to tell it to. Tears for this too ... And they came down in a flood ...
column2: Omijé ṣarajọ sójú Làbákẹ́, omijé fún Àlàmú, omijé fún nǹkan tí ó jẹ́ níyà lọ́wọ́ ìyá Àlàmú. Báwo ni Àlàmú  ṣe fẹ́ mọ̀ ohun tí ó là kọjá? Báwo ni yóò ṣe mọ̀ bí ìyá rẹ̀ ṣe sọ̀rọ̀ fitafita pẹ̀lú ìrunú? Àti àwọn ìfẹ̀sùnkàn búburú! Ta ló máa wá gbẹ̀rí rẹ̀ jẹ́? Ó gbé gbogbo èyí sọ́kàn. Kò sẹ́ni tí á bá sọ ọ́. Omijé fún èyí náà ... gọ̀ọ̀rọ̀gọ̀ ni ó sì dà wálẹ̀ bí odò ...

column1: All Alamu cared for now was his files, his cigarettes and his beer. Nothing else.
column2: Gbogbo ohun tí Àlàmú ń rí rò báyìí ò ju àwọn ìwé rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú sìgá àti ọtí rẹ̀. Kò sí nǹkan mìíràn mọ́.

column1: There he was now at the bottle laughing his rib-splitting laughter, feeling really on top of the world!
column2: Ibẹ̀ ló tún wà yìí, nídìí ìgò tí ó ń rín ẹ̀rín àrín kán-ní-hà rẹ̀, tí ó ṣe bí ìgbà tí gbogbo ayé wà ní ìkáwọ́ rẹ̀!

column1: Tinu crawled to him and stood in front of him with her shaky, delicate soft tiny legs. The little girl smiled, showing her newly-formed front teeth, like she did to her mother, now instinctely asking her father to see and admire them.
column2: Tinú rá lọ bá a, ó sì dúró síwájú rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ẹsẹ̀ ẹlẹgẹ́ kékeré rẹ̀ tí ó máa ń gbọ̀n. Ọmọ kékeré náà rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́, ó ń sàfihàn eyín rẹ̀ tuntun tó sẹ̀ẹ̀hù bí ó ṣe ṣe sí ìyá rẹ̀, ó ń fi ọgbọ́n inú sọ fún bàbá rẹ̀ pé kí ó rí i kí ó sì jọ̀ ọ́ lójú.

column1: Pa pa pa... Papa... Papapa...' Tinu babbled, She could now stand up straight on her two tiny legs without support. She was probably expecting daddy to congratulate her, before she would proceed to delivering a message - that message!
column2: Bà bà bà ...bàbá...bababa...', Tinú ń sọ̀rọ̀ wẹ́wẹ́, Ó ti wá lè dá dúró lórí ẹsẹ̀ rẹ̀ tín-ín-rín-tín méjì yẹn láìsí ìrànwọ́. Ó ń dúró pé kí bàbá kì í kú orí ire, kí ó tó di wí pé ó tẹ̀síwájú láti jẹ́ isẹ́ kan – iṣẹ́ yẹn!

column1: Alamu took a look at his daughter, and then took a look at the bottle of beer in front of him. He seemed to be holding a silent debate within himself over which one to choose... Alamu took another swig from the bottle. He seemed to prefer the bottle!
column2: Àlàmú wo ọmọ rẹ̀, ó sì tún wo ìgò ọtí iwájú rẹ̀. Ó fẹ́ jọ pé ó ń jiyàn kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ lórí èyí tí yóò mú... Àlàmú  gbé ọtí náà mu kíákíá, ó dàbí i pé ó fẹ́ ìgò ọtí náà ju ọmọ rẹ̀ lọ!

column1: Then he recoiled and took a hateful look at the intruding little rat in front of him. It was a rather sullen, distant look, as if he was seeing his own child for the first time. He laughed a vociferous laughter. Little Tinu screamed. And crying, she scrambled away on all fours, not waiting to deliver any message.
column2: Lẹ́yìn náà ó fa sẹ́yìn, ó sì wo eku kékeré iwájú rẹ̀ ní ìwò ìrira. Ó jẹ́ ìwò ìbínú tó jinná, bí ìgbà tí ó sẹ̀sẹ̀ ń rí ọmọ tirẹ̀fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́. Ó rín ẹ̀rín aláriwo. Tinú kékeré han. Pẹ̀lú igbe ó rá kúrò láídúró jísẹ́ kankan.

column1: Inside the matrimonial home, Labake literally saw a lurid cloud of smoke, Alamu had set his own home on fire, it appeared. And his mother has readily assisted, sprinkling petrol on the burning roof, to make it an inferno! And what would you do when you find yourself deep inside an inferno? When fire appeared on the mountain? Run, not so?
column2: Nínú ilé ìgbéyàwó yìí, Làbákẹ́ rí àgbájọ èéfín tó pòkudu, Àlàmú ti dá iná sí ilé tirẹ̀ ganan, ó farahàn. Ìyá rẹ̀ sì ti ràn-án lọ́wọ́ láti wọ́n bẹntiróòlù sórí òrùlé tó ń jóná náà, láti sọ ọ́ di iná ńlá! Kí sì ni ènìyàn lè ṣe bí ó bá bá ara rẹ̀ nínú iná àìlééru báyìí? Bí iná bá ń jó lórí òkè gíga? Àfi kí ènìyàn sáré, àbí bẹ́ẹ̀kọ́?

column1: Labake knew what to do. And she set about the business of packing cautiously and methodically. On the day she started, she stood on the balcony of the house and listened as Alamu revived the engine of his old Volkswagen in the garage and later backed the car out. She waited patiently until the car disappeared into the corner of the street with its usual trail of smoke and ear-splitting noise. The she ran back into the room.
column2: Làbákẹ́ mọ ohun tí yóò ṣe. Ó sì bẹrẹ̀ ìpalẹ̀mọ́ lẹ́sẹẹsẹ àti létòlétò. Ní ọjọ́ tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, ó dúró sí ọ̀dẹ̀dẹ̀ ilé wọn, ó sì ń tẹ́tí sí bí Àlàmú ṣe ń ṣáná sí ẹ́ńjíìnì ọkọ̀ gbígbó rẹ̀ nínú ọgbà ìgbọ́kọ̀sí, nígbà tó sìyá ọkọ náà fẹ̀yìn rìn jáde. Ó dúró pẹ̀lú sùúrù pé kí ọkọ̀ náà pòórá sí kọ̀rọ̀ òpópònà pẹ̀lú èéfín àdámọ́ àti ariwo ajánilétí rẹ̀. Lẹ́yìn náà ni ó sáré wọ yàrá.

column1: Inside the room, Labake flew at the standing hanger and started removing her clothes. Hurriedly, she pressed them inside the trunk boxes. Two cupboards inside the room contained trinklets and toiler articles and she started packing the items inside two empty raffia basket containers.
column2: Nínú yàrá, Làbákẹ́ bọ́ ìfasokọ́sí, ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í i yọ àwọn aṣọ rẹ̀. Kíá, ó ti kó wọn sínú àpótí aṣọ. Ohun ẹ̀ṣọ́ ara ni ókún inú kọ́ńbọ́ọ̀dù méjì nínú yàrá náà, ó sì kó àwọn nǹkan inú rẹ̀ sínú apẹ̀rẹ̀ rafia òfìfo méjì ní kíákíá.

column1: She stopped briefly and heaved a sigh ... Was she not runnign mad herself? Going crazy? How was she going to pack everything in the room without anybody’s assistance? Her eyes caught the standing fan, the standing mirror and the movable wardrobe. Better to leave those till the last minute. They could be left where they are for the time being.
column2: Ó dáwọ́ dúró díẹ̀, ó sì mí àmíkàn... ṣé òun fúnrarẹ̀ ò máa ya wèrè báyìí? Ṣé kò máa sínwín? Báwo ni yóò ṣe kó gbogbo nǹkan inú yàrá láìsẹni tí á ràn án lọ́wọ́? Ojú rẹ̀ lọ́ sí ibi fáánù adádúró, ibi dígí adádúró àti ilé ìfaṣọpamọ́sí tó ṣe é gbé. Á dáa kí ó fi gbogbo ìyẹn sílẹ̀ ná. Wọ́n ṣì lè wà níbi tí wọn wa yẹn ná.

column1: An hour later, the sound of Alamu’s car came to her ears ... Coming back home so soon today?
column2: Lẹ́yìn wákàtí kan, ohun ọkọ̀ Àlàmú tún wá sí etí rẹ̀ ... Ó tún tètè wálé lónìí?

column1: Hurriedly Labake pushed the trunk boxes to the back of the door, closed the two cupboards, pressed the raffia baskets under the family bed, wiped the perspiration off her brow and came out of the room trying to look cool and collected ... Wasn’t she running mad too? Wasn’t she really going mad? She started breathing heavily.
column2: Kíákíá ni Làbákẹ́ ti àwọn àpótí aṣọ náà sí ẹ̀yìn ilẹ̀kùn, ó pa pẹpẹ méjèèjì dé, ó ti àwọn apẹ̀ẹ̀rẹ̀ náàbọ abẹ́ ìbùsùn ẹbí, ó nu òógùn kúrò ní òkè ojú rẹ̀ ó sì jáde kúrò nínú yàrá, ó ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe dáadáa... Ṣe òun náà ò ti wá máa ya wèrè? Ṣe kò máa sínwín báyìí? Ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í mí kíkankíkan.

column1: The following morning, she swung into real action, she dressed up, hooked her small handbag under her left armpit, and soon she was on the street hailing a taxi. As she waited for one she silently rehearsed the story she was soon going to relate. It must be neatly related convincingly. Nothing must be left out.
column2: Lówùúrọ́ ọjọ́ kejì, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ isẹ́ rẹ̀ ní pẹrẹu, ó múra, ó fi báàgì ìfàlọ́wọ́ sí abíyá apá òsì, láìpẹ́ ó ti wà ní òpòpónà tí ó ń pe kabúkabú. Bí ó ṣe ń dúró de kabúkabú ni ó ń ronú nǹkan tí yóò sọ. Ó gbọ́dọ̀ sọ̀rọ̀ dáadáa tí yóò dánilójú. Kò sì gbọdọ̀ yọ nǹkankan sílẹ̀.

column1: It took Labake more than thirty minutes to get to her destination. Oke-Are was not too direct form Oke-Ado. There was the Beere traffic jam to put up with. The perennial ‘hold-up along Agbeni - Lebanon Street, not to talk of the menace of the danfo and taxi drivers around Ogunpa. The more direct Gege -  Okefofo road had been blocked as a result of a deep trench dug by the Water men. The trench had been there for some two months but noiselessly into an annhs or so, and it appeared the Water men were in no hurry at all to fill it up. So, it was now the longer route which Labake took, but, finally she got to Oke-Ado and entered the lawyers’ chambers. The signboard was imposing.
column2: Ó gba Làbákẹ́ ni bí i ọgbọ̀n ìṣẹ́jú kí ó tó débi tó ń lọ. Òkè-Àrẹ kò lọ tààrà láti Òkè-Àdó. Ó sì ní láti kọjà níbi sún-kẹrẹ-fà-kẹrẹ ọkọ̀ ní Bẹẹrẹ. Èyí tó sì wà ní òpópònà Agbeni sí Lẹbanon ò gbẹ́yìn, kí a tó wásọ ti ìwàkuwà àwọn awakọ̀ dánfó àti kabúkabú lágbèègbè Ògùnpa. Ọ̀nà tí ó ṣe tààrà láti Gẹ́gẹ́ sí Òkèfòkò látàrí kòtò ńlá tí àwọn olómi gbẹ́ síbẹ̀. Ihò  náà á ti máa lo bí i oṣù méjì tábì jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, ó sì jọ wí pé àwọn olómi  náà kò kánjú láti dí i pa.  Fún  ìdí èyí, ọ̀nà tí ó gùn jù ni Làbákẹ́ gbà, ṣùgbọ́n ó jàjà dé Òkè-Àdó, ó sì wọ ọ̀fìisi àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò lọ. Pátákó ìjúwe  náà mú ni lọ́kàn.

column1: As she stepped into the receptionist’s office, her heart started beating fast. She filled in the visitor’s slip with trembling fingers, took a seat and looked round strangely, almost timidly. Everything in the lawyers’ chambers followed a definitely rigid pattern; the way she was welcomed; the way answers were given to her requests.
column2: Bí ó ṣe wọ inú ọ́fíìsi olùgbàlejò, ọ̀kan rẹ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i ṣe kì-kì-kì. Ó ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ rẹ̀ sínú ìwé pélébé àlejò, ó ḿu ìjokòó ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i wò rá-rà-rá, tìbẹ̀rù tìbẹ̀rù. Gbogbo nǹkan inú ọ́fíìsì àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò yìí ni ó ní bátànì, bí wọ́n ṣe kí i káàbọ̀; ìkíni rẹ̀ àti bí wọ́n ṣe ń dáhùn ìbéèrè.

column1: Good day madam.
column2: Ẹ kú ojúmọ́ ìyá.

column1: Here to see the lawyer?
column2: Ẹ fẹ́ rí Agbẹjọ́rò?

column1: That’s right, please take your seat, you are welcome.
column2: Ó dáa bẹ́ẹ̀, ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ jókòó, ẹ káàbọ̀.

column1: Could you fill this slip? O.K. I’ll be back right now’. the receptionist walked briskly, but noiselessly into an inner office with the visitors’ slip, and returned exactly two minutes later.
column2: Ṣe ẹ lè ṣe àkọ́sílẹ̀ yìí? Ó dáa. Mò ńbọ̀ nísìnyí”, olùgbàlejò  náà rìn kíà láìpariwo lọ inú ọ́fíìsì kan nínú, ó sì padà dé lẹ́yìn ìṣẹ́jú méjì gérégé.

column1: "You will please hold on madam, for about five minutes."
column2: "Ẹ máa ní láti dúró ìyá, fún bí ìṣẹ́jú márùn-ún".

column1: Labake saw the pictures of the two lawyers running the chambers hanging on the wall. They both wore the typical lawyer’s look - unsmiling; stern-looking; brows knitted; lips tensed; uncompromising features and a penetrating gaze- strong enough to make the beholder blush. One of them wore dark glasses and looked familiar to Labake.
column2: Làbákẹ́ rí àwòrán agbẹjọ́rò méjì tí ó darí ọ́fíísì náà tí wọn gbé kọ́ ògiri. Àwọn méjéèjì múra bí i agbẹjọ́rò – láìrẹ́rìn-ín pẹ̀lú ojú líle wọn fa ojú ro ẹnu wọn padé, àwọn àbùdá tí kì í jẹ́kí ènìyàn ṣe àní-àní, àti ìwò àrímáleèlọ ni wọ́n ní tí ó ń mú ẹni yòówù tí ó bá rí wọn gbàgbé ara wọn. Ọ̀kan lára wọn lo ìgò dúdú ojú rẹ̀ sì jọ ojú mímọ̀ sí Làbákẹ́.

column1: After exactly five minutes, Labake was ushered into a room where one of the lawyers, Akanni Mustafa was waiting to receive her.
column2: Lẹ́yìn ìsẹ́jú márùn-ún géérégé, wọn pe Làbákẹ́ wọ yàrá kan, tí ọ̀kan ninú àwọn lọ́yà, ìyẹn Àkànní Mústàfá ti ń dúró láti gbà á lálejò.

column1: "You are welcome madam".
column2: "Ẹ káàbọ̀ ìyá"

column1: "Please pull a chair, we are at your service, what’s the problem? Take it easy, take everything easy".
column2: "Ẹ mú àga kan, a wà níbí fún  yín, kí ló sẹlẹ̀? Ẹ ṣe jẹ́jẹ́, ẹ ṣe gbogbo ǹkan jẹ́jẹ́".

column1: Barrister Mustafa had obviously noticed the anxiety on the face of Labake.
column2: Amòfin Mústàfá ti ṣàkíyèsí hílà-hílo tí ó hàn lójú Làbákẹ́.

column1: He was an experienced lawyer who knew how best to put the clients’ mind at ease.
column2: Ó jẹ́ agbẹjọ́rò tí ó ní ìrírí tí ó sì mọ bí wọ́n ṣe ń fi ọkàn oníbàárà balẹ̀.

column1: Whatever was the magnitude of the problem, he knew that clients would always display fear and anxiety.
column2: Kò síbí ìṣòro náà ṣe lè pọ̀ tó, ó mọ̀ pé àwọn oníbàárà máa ń gbé ìbẹ̀rù àti hílà-hílo wọn sójú.

column1: Those who came for criminal cases were usually the most difficult to handle.
column2: Àwọn tí ó bá bá ọ̀rọ̀ ọ̀ràn wá ní wọn máa ń le láti kojú jù.

column1: They would relate their experience sobbing, biting their lips, sucking their fingertips, and pulling at the hair.
column2: Wọn á máa sọ ìrírí wọn tẹkúntẹkún, wọn á má a gé ètè ara wọn jẹ, wọn á má fa orí ìka ọwọ́ wọn mú tàbí kí wọn máa fa irun ara wọn.

column1: And this always made it difficult, if not impossible, to get details immediately.
column2: Àwọn èyí sì má a ń jẹ́ kí ó le tàbí, kí ó má ṣe é ṣe láti rí àlàyé kíkún gbà lẹ́nu wọn.

column1: For them, the fact-finding investigation had to be conducted very tactfully.
column2: Fún irú wọn, ìwádìí òtítọ́ ní láti wáyé pẹ̀lú ọgbọ́n ẹ̀wẹ́.

column1: Otherwise, there would be loop-holes created here and there to the advantage of the opposing camp.
column2: Láìjẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀ àwọn ìhò a pọ̀ fún àǹfààní àwọn ọ̀tá láti rí wọ̀.

column1: But those who came for civil cases were milder and easier to handle.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn tí wọn bá bá ẹjọ́ abẹ́lé wá máa ń rọrùn láti gbámú.

column1: With occasional expressions of griefs, clients in this category would shout their innocence and speak a large part of truth - if not the whole truth.
column2: Wọn a máa fi ẹ̀dùn ọkàn wọn hàn lẹ́ẹ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan oníbàárà ní abẹ́ ọ̀wọ́ yìí máa ń fọnrere àìmọ́wọ mẹsẹ̀ wọn, wọ́n sì máa ń sọ púpọ̀ òótọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ wọn ìyẹn tí kì í báá ṣe òótọ́ pọ́nbélé.

column1: And if you cross-examined them twenty times they would repeat the same account with just a little, or no contradiction at all.
column2: Bí ènìyàn bá sì ṣàgbéyẹ̀wò nǹkan tí wọn bá sọ nígbà ogún, nǹkan kan  náà ni ẹni  náà á gbọ́ lẹ́nu wọn pẹ̀lú ìyàtọ̀ bín-ín-tín  tàbí  kí ó má sì ìyàtọ̀ kankan rárá.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa put Labake in the second category. He was right.
column2: Irú ọwọ́ yìí ni agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá fi Làbákẹ́ sí. Ó sì tọ̀nà bẹ́ẹ̀.

column1: Breathlessly, Labake related her experience in her matrimonial home, she traced the story of her happy love affair with Alamu right from the time they were in England through to the time they arrived in Nigeria for the marriage, which was celebrated with pomp and peageantry.
column2: Láísìnmi, Làbákẹ́ ròyìn gbogbo ìrírí rẹ̀ nílé ọkọ rẹ̀, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìtàn ìfẹ́ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú Àlàmú  láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀, nígbà tí wọn wà nílùú Englandi títí di ìgbà tí wọ́n fi dé orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà fún ìgbéyàwó tí wọ́n ṣe táyé gbọ́ tọ́run mọ̀.

column1: Hopes were high for a great future as Alamu secured the lucrative job of an Accountant in the reputable Bajoks Company Limited and their child, Tinu, arrived to add to their joy.
column2: Ìrètí wọn fún  ọjọ́ iwájú wọn ga bí Àlàmú ṣe rísẹ́ asírò-ọ̀rọ̀ sílé iṣẹ́ Bajoks tó gbajúmọ̀, àti ọmọ wọn Tinú tó dé láti wá dákún ayọ̀ wọn.

column1: From then on, fate struck a devastating blow and the matrimonial life.
column2: Lẹ́yìn ìgbà  náà ní ìjì bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í jà tí ọkọ̀ ìgbéyàwó wọn bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í kọsẹ̀.

column1: Each the woeful event came vividly to her mind, and with the force and reality of a picture-strip from a film projector.
column2: Gbogbo ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà ń wá sí i lọ́kàn kedere bí ìgbà tí ó bá sẹ̀sẹ̀ ń sẹlẹ̀.

column1: She related the story of her husband’s deterioration and his eccentric habits at home.
column2: Ó sọ ìtàn ìfàsẹ́yìn ọkọ rẹ̀ àti àwọn ìṣe aágà nná tí ó ń ṣe nílé.

column1: Her eyes welled up in tears when she came to the role her old mother-in-law was playing in the whole affair.
column2: Ojú rẹ̀ kúnfún  omijé nígbà tí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ débi ipa tí ìyá ọkọ rẹ̀ ń kó nínú gbogbo ọ̀rọ̀ náà.

column1: That was to her, the final straw breaking the camels back.
column2: Sí i ìyẹn ni àjẹǹjẹtán ọ̀rọ̀ náà.

column1: Labake did not know how best to knit the events together to make a good case for a divorce suit.
column2: Làbákẹ́ ò mọ ònà tí ó dára jù láti so gbogbo ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà pọ̀ láti lè fi ṣe ẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀ gidi.

column1: By the time she’d finished her story, she’d become so completely overcome, she felt so hot all over the body even though the air-conditioner was switched to its maximum  in the lawyer’s office.
column2: Nígbà tí ó máa fi parí ìtàn rẹ̀, ó dàbí i pé wọ́n ti borí, ọ̀rọ̀ náà ti gbọ̀n-ọ́n, ooru mú un ní gbogbo ara, bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ẹ̀rọ amúlétutù wà ní títàn dé góńgó nínú ọ́fíísì agbẹjọ́rò náà.

column1: Alright... Alright madam. Take it easy madam, we have a case ... a good case.
column2: Ó dáa ... Ó dáa ìyáàfin, ẹ ṣe jẹ́jẹ́ ìyáàfin, à ti lẹ́jọ́ ... ẹjọ́ tó dára.

column1: We have good grounds to start a divorce suit.
column2: A sì ti ní ìpìlẹ̀ tó dára láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa pressed a button and it was then that Labake saw, for the first time that all what she said had been tape-recorded.
column2: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá tẹ bọ́tìnì kan, ìgbà  náà ni Làbákẹ́ sẹ̀sẹ̀ rí i pé gbogbo nǹkan tí òun sọ ni wọ́n ti gbà sílẹ̀.

column1: That, of course, did not matter much to her it was the way of the lawyers.
column2: Gbogbo èyí kò kúkú kàn án, ọ̀nà àwọn agbẹjọ́rò nìyẹn.

column1: All she wanted was a quick nullification of the marriage contract. No more no less. And she had every confidence in his lawer whom everybody in town knew for his fearlessness and competence in interpreting the law.
column2: Gbogbo nǹkan tí ó ń fẹ́ ni ìtúká ìgbéyàwó náà ní kíákíá. Kò fẹ́ nǹkan mìíràn lẹ́yìn ìyẹn. Ó sì ní ìgbàgbọ́ nínú agbẹjọ́rò tí gbogbo ènìyàn ìgboro mọ̀ nígbòro fún àìníbẹ̀rù rẹ̀ àti ìgbójú rẹ̀ nínú títúmọ̀ òfin.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa and his partner had the reputation of handling seemingly hopeless cases, holding the court spellbound, confusing the  opponents with incontrovertible evidence.
column2: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá àti ẹnìkejì rẹ̀ ní orúkọ nípa kíkápá ẹjọ́ tí a rò pé kò nírètí mọ́ nípa lílo ẹ̀rí tó yèkoro láti ka kóòtù ní ẹ̀jafúú àti láti dà òpó àwọn alátakò rú pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rí tó dájú.

column1: "We have a good case madam", he repeated, "No need o worry".
column2: "A ní ẹjọ́ tó dára ìyáàfin", ó tún un sọ, "Ẹ kò nílò láti dààmú".

column1: We are going to file a divorce suit on five grounds: drunkenness, wickedness, dereliction of duty, neglect of responsibility and total disrespect for thee sacred oath of the Marriage Act on the part of your husband’.
column2: A máa fi ẹ̀sùn yìí kàn lórí ẹ̀sùn márùn-ún yìí; ọtí àmupara, ìwà ìkà, àìka isẹ́-ẹni sí, fífi ojúṣe-ẹni sílẹ̀ àti àìbọ̀wọ̀ fún ìgbéyàwó fún ọkọ yín.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa finished, chuckling confidently.
column2: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá parí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ ó sì rẹ́rìn-ín pẹ̀lú ìgboyà.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa asked Labake a few other minor questions about the home and requested her to submit to them at the chambers, her marriage certificate and wedding ring for inspection - also their wedding album.
column2: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá bí Làbákẹ́ ní àwọn ìbéèrè kéékèèké mìíràn nípa ilé, ó sì sọ fún  un pé kí ó mú àwọn ìwé-ẹ̀rí àti òrùka ìgbéyàwó wá fún ìtọpinpin àti ìwé àkojọpọ̀àwòrán ìgbéyàwó wọn náà.

column1: After that, they would sit down, and determine what her bill would be - how much she would pay, and the rest.
column2: Lẹ́yìn èyí ni wọ́n á jòkòó, wọn á sì wo iye owó tí yóò san, owó iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ àti àwọn nǹkan yòókù.

column1: "It’s a pity madam", Lawyer Mustafa said, ‘my partner is out.
column2: "Ó ṣeni láàánú ìyá", Agbejọ́rò Mústàfá ń bá ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ bọ̀, "Ẹnìkejì mi jáde".

column1: You will have the opportunity of meeting him when next you come.
column2: Ẹ̀ ẹ́ ní àǹfààní láti mọ̀ ọ́n nígbà tí ẹ bá tún wá.

column1: We are always together.... You know, putting heads together to crack the nut of stubborn cases. Two heads are better than one, as people say.
column2: A jọ máa ń wà pọ̀ ni .... Ṣé ẹ mọ̀, kí a foríkorí láti fọ agbọ̀n ẹjọ́ tó bá yi. Orí méjì sàn ju ọ̀kan bí àwọn ènìyàn ṣe máa ń sọ.

column1: I’ll brief him fully about your suit... in case my plan to travel abroad next week materializes, he’ll take over your case.
column2: Máa sọ ọ̀rọ̀ ẹjọ́ yín fún un... aìíbaàámọ̀ èrò mi láti lọ sí ìlú ọba lè wá sí ìmúsẹ lọ́sẹ̀ tó ń bọ̀, òun ni yóò bá  a yín máa bá ẹjọ́ náà lọ.

column1: We are one and the same, no problem. Labake smiled, the battle was, indeed, half-won. With these two sharp lawyers battling it out on her behalf in court, she had nothing to fear, she was going to defeat Alamu hands down.
column2: Ọ̀kanṣoṣo ni wá, nǹkankan  náà sì ní wá pẹ́lù, kò sí ìṣòro. Làbákẹ́ rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́, ó ti ja ogun náà ní àjàyè dé ìdajì. Pẹ̀lú ìrànwọ́ àwọn agbejọ́rò tó múnádoko méjì yìí nílé ẹjọ́, kò ní nǹkankan láti bẹ̀rù, yóò borí Àlàmú délẹ̀.

column1: When finally Labake rose to go, her countenance had brightened. Her heart had stopped beating that confused rhythm. And what she heard finally from Lawyer Mustafa raised her spirit and cheered her heart. It was like tonic to a troubled heart.
column2: Nígbà tí Làbákẹ́ jàjà dìde láti máa lọ, ojú rẹ̀ ti yàtọ̀. Ọkàn rẹ̀ ti ṣíwọ́ lílù kì-kì-kì. Òhun tí ó sì gbọ́ lẹ́nu Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá gbẹ̀yìn gbé ẹ̀mí rẹ̀ sókè, ó sì dá ọkàn rẹ̀ lárayá. Ó dàbí i òògùn ẹ̀jẹ̀ sí ọkàn tí ó ti pòrúurù.

column1: "No problem about the little child - your child, Lawyer Mustafa assured, she will be adequately catered for in the suit, we know how to do that", the Lawyer calmed her again.
column2: "Kò sí ìṣòro nípa ti ọmọ kékeré yẹn-ọmọ yín, amáa ṣètọ́jú tirẹ̀ nínú ẹjọ́ náà, a mọ bí a ṣe máa ṣe é", Agbẹjọ́rò tún fi ọkàn rẹ̀ balẹ̀.

column1: Labake walked out of the lawyer’s office smiling at the courteous receptionist.
column2: Làbákẹ́ rìn jáde nínú ọ́fíisì agbẹjọ́rò náà pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rín músẹ́ sí olùgbàlejò ọlọ́yàyà  náà.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa’s eyes followed his prospective client out.
column2: Ojú Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá tẹ̀lé oníbàárà rẹ̀ jáde.

column1: What a thoroughly disillusioned that young lady she was.
column2: Irú arábìnrin aláìlẹ́tàn tí ó jẹ́.

column1: A lady who had seen the troubles of marraige just once and thinks it would crush her. The problem with her was the problem with thousands of other young housewives in town.
column2: Obìnrin tí ó ti rí wàhálà ìgbéyàwó ní ẹ̀ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo, ti ó wá ń rò ó pé ọ̀runfúnrarẹ fẹ́ wó pa á. Ìṣòro tí ó ní yìí náà ní ìṣòro tí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn ìyàwó-ilé kéé-kèè-ké mìíràn ń ní nígboro.

column1: The women would have sleepless nights over small matrimonial matters.
column2: Àwọn obìnrin náà ń ṣe àìsùn lóru lórí ọ̀rọ̀ tí ò tó nǹkan nínú ìgbéyàwó.

column1: They would lament and curse the day they were married!
column2: Wọn á rojọ́, wọn à sì gégùn-ún fún  ọjọ́ tí wọn ṣe ìsopọ̀ tọkọtaya!

column1: They would swear the end had come.
column2: Wọn á búra pé òpin ti dé.

column1: They would threaten to take poison, and what they fret so much about, in most cases, are matters that could be amicably settled out of court by their respective parents at home.
column2: Wọn á halẹ̀ láti gbé májèlé jẹ, àwọn nǹkan tí ó ń bí wọn nínú lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà kìí tó nǹkan, irú àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ ṣe é yanjú nílé pẹ̀lú àwọn òbí wọn láìdélé ẹjọ́.

column1: It was either that the husband stayed in the office doing over-time work with the lady secretary for company; that would not eat well at home - indicating that he’d satisfied himself somewhere outside; that he sleeps off immediately after dinner and would not wake up till early the following morning; that he would talk in his sleep about some secret lover or that the husband no longer placed his fat salary at the disposal of members of the household; that he was tied to the apron strings of his parents, neglecting her - the lady of the house and so forth.
column2: Ó lè jẹ́ pé ọkọ pẹ́ níbisẹ́ tí ó ń ṣe àṣekún iṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú akọ̀we rẹ̀ obìnrin; tí ò sì jẹun dáadáa nílé, ìyẹn ń túmọ̀ sí pé ó tí tẹ ara rẹ̀ lọ́rùn níbìkan ni; bí ó bá sùn ní kété tó jẹun alẹ́ tí ò sì jí títí tí ilẹ̀ ọjọ́ kejì fi mọ́; tàbí ó sọ̀rọ̀ olólùfẹ́ ìkọ̀kọ̀ láti ojú oorun tàbí pé ọkọ ò gbé owó oṣù rẹ̀ lé bùkátà àwọn ara ilé mọ̀ tàbí  pé ó sọ ara rẹ̀ mọ́ àwọn òbí rẹ̀ jú, tí ó sì gbójúfò òun dá - ìyẹn ìyàwó ilé àti àwọn ìdí bẹ́è bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa watched Labake walk away. He was full of pity for her.
column2: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá wo Làbákẹ́ bí ó ṣe ń rìn lọ, tí àánú rẹ̀ sì ń ṣe é.

column1: If only woman would learn to endure and men would learn to be patient; if only couples would learn to talk over their grievances with mutual love and respect, and laugh over their mistakes and failures, surely, bitterness would find no place in their homes and the question of going to court to settle scores would be entirely out of it. But then, that would put lawyers out of business.
column2: Bí àwọn obìnrin bá lè kọ́ bí a ṣe ń rọ́jú, kí àwọn ọkùnrin náà kọ́ bí a ṣe ń ní sùúrù; bí àwọn tokọtaya bá lè kọ́ bí á ṣe ń sọ̀rọ̀ lórí ìbànújẹ́ wọn pẹ̀lú àjọpín ìfẹ́ àti ìbọ̀wọ̀ kí wọ́n sì rẹ́rìn-ín lórí gbogbo àṣìṣe àti ìkùnà wọn, dájúdájú ìkorò ò ní ráyè nínú ilé wọn, kò sì ní sí ìdí láti gbẹ́jọ́ wọn délé ẹjọ́ kí wọn tó parí ẹ̀. Ṣùgbọ́n báyẹn, àwọn agbẹjọ́rò ò ní rí isẹ́ ṣe.

column1: Lawyer Mustafa knew it was good that he had agreed to help Labake prosecute the case.
column2: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá mọ̀ pé ó dára bí òun ṣe gbà láti bá Làbákẹ́ ṣe ẹjọ́ náà.

column1: Labake was satisfied, she arrived back at home a satisfied woman.
column2: Ó tẹ́ Làbákẹ́ lọ́rùn, ó délé padà bí obìnrin tí ó ní ìtẹ̀lọ́rùn.

column1: But with one resolution: that she would henceforth meet force with force.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú ìpinnu kan nipé òun a máa gbé ipá wojú ipá ni.

column1: If Alamu was dumb, she too would seal her own lips completely.
column2: Bí Àlàmú bá ya odi, òun náà a se ètè tirẹ̀ pátápátá.

column1: If he shouted at her, she too would yell back at him.
column2: Bí ó bá pariwo mọ́ ọn, òun náà á pariwo padà.

column1: If Alamu laughed out to her, the usual way - like a mad man, she too would open her mouth wide and trumpet her laughter - so loud it would make Alamu himself tremble!
column2: Bí Àlàmú bá rẹ́rìn-ín aláriwo sí i bí ó ṣe máa ń rín in bí i wèrè, òun náà á lánu tirẹ̀ fẹ̀, á sì rín ẹ̀rín aláriwo tirẹ̀ padà, ariwo rẹ̀ á pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí Àlàmú fúnrarẹ á gbọ̀n rìrì!

column1: Henceforth, it was going to be the tramp facing the lunatic inside a mad house in open combat! Two forces.
column2: Láti ìsìnyí lọ, ọ̀rọ̀ wọn á di ti alárìnkiri tí ó kọjúmọ́ asínwín nílé wèrè, ní ìjàkadì gbangba! Agbára ipá méjì.

column1: Then the inevitable explosion which would for ever separate them.
column2: Lẹ́yìn náà ni ti ariwo tí ò ṣe é sá fún tí yóò tú wọn ká títí láé.

column1: The voice of Tinu came to Labake from the  backyard of their flat - mocking her or so it seemed.
column2: Ohùn Tinú wá sí etí Làbákẹ́ láti ẹ̀hìnkùlé ilé wọn – bí ìgbà tí ó bá ń ṣe yẹ̀yẹ́ ní o jọ́.

column1: ‘Tata - Tatata - Papapa Papa - Papapa’. The little girl staggered towards the sitting room and saw her mother. Then she changed her mind.
column2: “Tata-tatata – bababa-baba-bababa”, ọmọ náà ta gbọ̀n-ọ́n gbọ̀n-ọ́n lọ́nà yàrá ìgbafẹ́, ó sì rí ìyá rẹ̀. Lẹ́yìn náà ní ó yí ọkàn padà.

column1: "Mama - ma ma ma ma - mama - mamama".
column2: "Màmá-ma ma ma –màmá-mamama"

column1: Labake smiled, what a sharp quick-witted child she was.
column2: Làbákẹ́ rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́, irú ọmọ tó gbọ́n wo rè é.

column1: If she had the gift of language, she would have long gone to deliver the message she sent her to her daddy.
column2: Bí ó bá jẹ́ pé ó ni ẹ̀bùn èdè ni, á tí jíṣẹ́ tí ó rán sí bàbá rẹ̀ tipẹ́tipẹ́.

column1: A very sharp, very inquisitive little girl, she would grow up in future with questions on her smart lips.
column2: Ọmọ tí ó dá ṣáṣá , tí ó gbọ́n, bí ó bá dàgbà lọ́jọ́ iwájú ìbéèrè ákún ẹnu rẹ̀.

column1: She would want to know why she was the victim of a broken home. Yes... She had  right to know.
column2: Á fẹ́ mọ̀ ìdí tí ó fi jẹ́ pé ilé tí ó túká ni òun ti wá. Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni... ó ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti mọ̀.

column1: Labake knew it would be imperative to satisfy Tinu with an explanation.
column2: Làbákẹ́ mọ̀ pé dandan ni kí òun fi àlàyé tẹ́ Tinú lọ́rùn.

column1: There was the need for her, henceforth, to start keeping a diary of the daily events at home.
column2: Ó nílò láti ní ìwé ìjẹ́rìí-ẹni tí yóò máa kọ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ojoojúmọ́ inú ilé náà sí.

column1: This diary she would show Tinu in future.
column2: Ìwé yìí ni á fi han Tinú lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

column1: And the poor girl, no doubt, would read it with tears in her eyes.
column2: Ọmọbìnrin aláìsẹ̀, náàá kàá pẹ̀lú omijé lójú láìsí àní-àní.

column1: Her father’s beer and how he vomitted on her, how he pushed her, how he kicked little Tinu herself, the poor girl screaming, tumbling, bruising her lips and the gum of her newly-formed teeth.
column2: Ọtí àmupara bàbá rẹ̀ – bí ó ṣe bì sí i lára tí ó sì tì í, ó ta á nípàá, tí ọmọ náà ń han, tí ó ń yíràá nílẹ̀ tí ó ṣèṣe létè àti èrìgì eyín tuntun rẹ̀ lọ́jọ kan.

column1: Her father’s madness and neglect, shirking all the responsibilities of a father and husband, his uproarious laughter and the detestable habit of keeping late hours outside.
column2: Wèrè àti ìtàdanù bàbá rẹ̀, tí ó ń gbọn ẹ̀tọ́ rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí i bàbá àti ọkọ dànù, ẹ̀rín aláriwo rẹ̀, àti wíwọlé lóru rẹ̀ bí ọrọ̀.

column1: All these things combining to push her to seek divorce, not to talk of the constant disgrace and embarrasment from Mama and the neighbours...
column2: Gbogbo èyí ló tì í láti sẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀, kí á tó wá sọ ti àbùkù ti màmá fi ń kàn án àti ìdààmú láti ọwọ́ màmá àti àwọn ará àdúgbò...

column1: Labake was right. The neighbours' attitude had started becoming more and more intolerable. Only last night Labake heard her neighbours talking to her again in the usual way; but this time in a tone that was both sarcastic and contemptuous.
column2: Òtítọ́ ni Làbákẹ́ sọ. Ìṣesí àwọn ará àdúgbò rẹ̀ kò ṣe é gbà sára rárá. Alẹ́ àná nàá ni Làbákẹ́ gbọ́ tí àwọn ará àdúgbò rẹ̀ tún ń bá a wí bí wọn ṣe máa ń sọ; Ṣùgbọ́n tọ̀tẹ̀ yìí ń pẹ̀gàn ni.

column1: He’s not only mad. She is mad too,
column2: Ọkọ nìkan kọ́ ló ya wèrè, Ìyàwó  náà ya wèrè,

column1: Two mad people. Mad home.
column2: Àwọn wèrè méjì . Ilé wèrè.

column1: She pretends not to hear us, what is she waiting for really? Tell us, mad woman...
column2: Ó ń díbọ́n bí ìgbà tí kò gbọ́ wa, kí ló ń dúró dè, lóòótọ́? Sọ fún  wa, wèrè obìnrin...

column1: They did not face her directly to talk. How then was she going to defend herself?
column2: Wọn kò kọjúsí i tààrà láti sọ̀rọ̀. Báwo ni yóò ṣe wá gbèjà ara rẹ̀?

column1: What a tantalising situation! A case of the prosecutor dragging the accused to court to pronounce judgment without a trial.
column2: Irú ipò ìyọnilẹ́nu wò rè é! Ọ̀rọ̀ wá di ti olùpéjọ́ ti ó ń wọ àfẹ̀sùnkàn lọ sí ilé ẹjọ́ láti dájọ́ láìsí ìpèléjọ́.

column1: Well, the whole world was apparently against her - Mama, Alamu, the neighbours and all.
column2: Gbogbo ayé ni wọn ti kẹ̀yìn si – Màmá, Àlàmú, àwọn ará àdúgbò àti gbogbo ènìyàn.

column1: So, nobody was going to stop her from pursuing the divorce suit to its logical conclusion.
column2: Fún ìdí èyí, kò sí ẹnìkan tí yóò díi lọ́wọ́ láti pe ẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀ náà títí dé òpin.

column1: If in future Tinu asked her questions, she too would have questions to ask Tinu in return, she would ask if Tinu, as a woman could have put up with such a situation and not seek divorce.
column2: Ní ọjọ́ iwájú, bí Tinú bá bi í ní ìbèérè, òun náà á ní ìbèérè láti bi Tinú padà, á bèrè bí Tinú náà bá lè gba irú rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí obìnrin, kí ó máa bèèr̀e fún  ìkọ́sílẹ̀.

column1: Alamu's head was up in the air.
column2: Orí Àlàmú wà lókè.

column1: He kept his eyes on the sitting room ceiling as he hurried out of the house clutching two files.
column2: Ó tẹjúmọ́ òkè àjà yàrá ìgbafẹ́ wọn bí ó ṣe ń kánjú kúrò nínú ilé tí ó sì mú ìwé méjì pọ.

column1: Labake too was hastening out of the kitchen. Husband and wife brushed past each other, chest to chest.
column2: Làbákẹ́ jáde láti ilé ìdáná. Ọkọ àti ìyàwó bá kọlu ara wọn, ní ìdàyà kọ àyà.

column1: The two files Alamu was holding dropped from his hand. And the empty kettle Labake was holding also fell from her hand.
column2: Àwọn ìwé méjì tí Àlàmú kó dání jábọ́ lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀. Bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni kẹ́tùlù tí Làbákẹ́ gbé dání náà jábọ́ lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀.

column1: It was not easy to apportion blame.
column2: Kò rọrùn láti dá ẹnìkan lẹ́bi.

column1: If Alamu had his eyes fixed up on the ceiling, Labake had hers probing down into the floor of the room.
column2: Bí ó bá jẹ́ pé Àlàmú ń tẹjú mọ́ òkè àjà ni, Làbákẹ́ náà tẹjú tirẹ̀ mọ ilẹ̀ ni bí ó ṣe ń rìn.

column1: For some seconds, they stood gazing at each other, questioning each other with a bad look.
column2: Fún bí i ìṣẹ́jú àáyá díẹ̀, wọ́n dúró ń wojú ara wọn, wọ́n ń fi ojú burúkú bi ara wọn léèrè.

column1: Alamu did not utter a word.
column2: Àlàmú  kò lanu sọ nǹkankan.

column1: Labake too did not open her lips.
column2: Làbákẹ́ náà ò sì la ẹnu rẹ̀.

column1: Silently, Alamu bent  down and picked up his files.
column2: Ní ìdákẹ́rọ́rọ́ ni Àlàmú bẹ̀rẹ̀ mọ́lẹ̀ tí ó sì kó ìwé rẹ̀.

column1: Labake too quietly stooped to pick her kettle ... And the two of them went their separate ways!
column2: Làbákẹ́ náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ gbé kẹ́tùlù nílẹ̀... Oníkálukú sì bá ọ̀nà tirẹ̀ lọ!

column1: To hell with this man! This terrible mad man
column2: Kò ní dá a fún ọkùnrin yìí! Ọmọkùnrin wèrè burúkú yìí.

column1: Labake seemed to be whispering to herself.
column2: Ó fẹ jọ wí pé Làbákẹ́ ń sọ èyí sí ara rẹ̀ ní kẹ́lẹ́kélẹ́.

column1: Force with force!  Nothing short of that! In a few days time, Alamu would get the court summons.
column2: Ipá pẹ̀lú ipá ni! Kò sí ohun mìíràn lẹ́yiǹ ìyẹn! Tí a bá máa fì rí ọjọ́ mélòó kan, Àlàmú á gba ìpèlẹ́jọ́ ilé ẹjọ́.

column1: His eyes would turn red and his lips would tremble like the leaves on the tree.
column2: Ojú rẹ̀ á pọ́n, ètè rẹ̀ á sì gbọ̀n bí i ewé orí igi.

column1: The summons would wake up all the ghosts inside his crazy head and send him off to the streets  blaring the wild meaningless song of a thoroughly mad man.
column2: Àwọn ìpèlẹ́jọ́ yẹn á jí gbogbo iwin inú orí ẹ̀ sílẹ̀, á sì rán an sí òpópónà káàkiri, á máa kígbe orin ẹhànnà aláìnítumọ̀ rẹ̀ kíkan kíkan tí ó jọ ti wèrè pọ́ńbélé.

column1: Of course, his mother would be hot on his heels on the streets shouting the eccentric chorus! That was his own palaver... And the palaver of this old witch he called his mother.
column2: Dájúdájú ẹsẹ̀ ìyà rẹ̀ a gbóná lórí òpópónà, tí yóò máa pariwo orin ayírí! Wàhálà tirẹ̀ niyẹn... àti wàhálà àjẹ́ àgbà tí ó pè ní ìyá rẹ̀.

column1: Labake watched, amused, each time Alamu cast his hungry look at the dining room table. He would, for some time gaze intently at the dining table at the usual meal times only to see empty water bottles, cups turned upside down and the unwashed plates piled up with flies at strategic positions, keeping vigilant watch!
column2: Làbákẹ́ ń wò pẹ̀lú ìyanú, nígbàkigbà tí Àlàmú  bá wo tábìlì yàrá ìjẹun tebi-tebi. A tẹjú mọ́ tábìlì náà ní às̀ikò tí ó yẹ kí oúnjẹ délẹ̀, Ṣùgbọ́n kòròfo ìgò omi, ife tí wọ́n dojú ẹ̀ kọlẹ̀ àti àwọn abọ́ ìdọ̀tí tí wọ́n tò jọ pẹ̀lú esinsin nípò wọn, tí wọn ń ṣisẹ́ ẹ̀sọ́!

column1: Labake had no explanation to give anybody anymore for her action.
column2: Kò sí àlàyé tí Làbákẹ́ fẹ́ ṣe fún ẹnikẹni lórí ìṣe rẹ̀.

column1: She was no longer accountable to anybody.
column2: Kò lè jábọ̀ fún ẹnikẹ́ni mọ́.

column1: She was no longer the lady of the house. She did not see herself as such anymore.
column2: Òun kọ́ ni ìyá-ilé mọ́, kò sì rí ara rẹ̀ bí i ọ̀kan mọ́.

column1: The lady of the house was the woman in perfect control of the affairs of the home.
column2: Ìyá-ilé ní obìnrin tí gbogbo ìsẹ̀lẹ̀ ilé máa ń wà ní ìkápá rẹ̀.

column1: The woman in love with her husband and the woman whom the husband admired in turn.
column2: Obìnrin tí ó nífẹ̀ẹ́ ọkọ rẹ̀, tí ọkọ rẹ̀ sì nífẹ̀ẹ́.

column1: The woman in the good books of the relatives of the husband.
column2: Obìnrin tí ó ní àkọ́sílẹ̀ rere lọ́dọ̀ àwọn ẹbí ọkọ rẹ̀ fún.

column1: So, Labake was not qualified.
column2: Ìdí èyí, Làbákẹ́ kò kún ojú òsùnwọ̀n.

column1: Now she was just a mere tenant in Alamu's house.
column2: Ayálégbé lásán ni nílé Àlàmú báyìí.
